{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2013}} [[File:International Media Council Delegation with Yasser Arafat in November 2004.jpg|thumb|320px|Yasser Arafat, November 2004, shortly before his death]] {{Infobox historical event |Event_Name = Death of [[Yasser Arafat]] |Imagesize = 260px |Thumb_Time = |AKA = |Location = [[Hôpital d'instruction des armées Percy]] in [[Clamart]], a suburb of [[Paris]], [[France]] |Date = {{Start date|df=yes|2004|11|11}} |Deaths = [[Yasser Arafat]] a.k.a. Mohammed Yasser Abdel Rahman Abdel Raouf Arafat al-Qudwa al-Husseini aka Abu Ammar; 75 |Result = Yasser Arafat's body buried in the [[Mukataa|Mukaata]], which was his compound in [[Ramallah]]. }} [[Yasser Arafat]], who was the [[President of the Palestinian National Authority]] and [[Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization]], died unexpectedly on 11 November 2004, 75 years of age, after a short period of illness. The '''cause of Arafat's death''' has since been debated, although several different theories concerning it have been suggested.
==History of illness== Arafat's illness began on 12 October 2004 with [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], [[abdominal pain]], and [[diarrhea]]. Soon afterward, his general health deteriorated.<ref name=pmid24120205>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(13)61834-6 |pmid=24120205 |title=Improving forensic investigation for polonium poisoning |journal=The Lancet |volume=382 |issue=9900 |pages=1308 |year=2013 |last1=Froidevaux |first1=Pascal |last2=Baechler |first2=Sébastien |last3=Bailat |first3=Claude J |last4=Castella |first4=Vincent |last5=Augsburger |first5=Marc |last6=Michaud |first6=Katarzyna |last7=Mangin |first7=Patrice |last8=Bochud |first8=François O }}</ref> Following visits by other doctors, including teams from Tunisia, Jordan, and Egypt, Arafat was taken to France on a French government jet, and was admitted to the [[Hôpital d'instruction des armées Percy]] in [[Clamart]], a suburb of Paris, on 29 October 2004.<ref name=pmid24120205/><ref name="Funeral">{{cite news|title=Arafat's funeral held in Cairo: Mystery illness |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4005027.stm|first=Peter|last=Biles|publisher=BBC|date=12 November 2004|accessdate=2 November 2007 }}</ref> On admission, he was suffering from diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and generalised abdominal pain, along with mild [[liver failure|liver]] and [[kidney failure]] linked to [[disseminated intravascular coagulation]].<ref name=pmid24120205/> His condition deteriorated with [[acute renal failure]], and, on 3 November, he lapsed into a gradually deepening coma.<ref name=pmid24120205/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.volokh.com/posts/chain_1100148783.shtml|title=Arafat: If he is "brain-dead," he is dead|first=Jim|last=Lindgren|date=4 November 2004|work=The Volokh Conspiracy using passage published by France-Press}}</ref>
A controversy erupted between officials of the PNA and [[Suha Arafat]] when officials from the PNA traveled to France to see Yasser Arafat. Suha stated, "They are trying to bury Abu Ammar [Arafat] alive".<ref>{{cite news|first=Julie|last=Stahl|title='They're Trying to Bury My Husband Alive' Suha Arafat Says|url=http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewForeignBureaus.asp?Page=/ForeignBureaus/archive/200411/FOR20041108c.html|work=CNS News|publisher=Cybercast News Service|date=8 November 2004|accessdate=11 October 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929103031/http://www.cnsnews.com/ViewForeignBureaus.asp?Page=%2FForeignBureaus%2Farchive%2F200411%2FFOR20041108c.html|archivedate=29 September 2007|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Law of France|French law]] forbids physicians from discussing the condition of their patients with anybody, with the exception, in the case of a grave prognosis, of close relatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/WAspad/UnArticleDeCode?commun=&code=CSANPUNL.rcv&art=L1110-4|title=Code of Public Health|date=5 March 2002|publisher=Legifrance|language=French}}</ref> Accordingly, all communications concerning Arafat's health had to be authorized by his wife. Palestinian officials expressed regret that the news about Yasser Arafat was "filtered" by her.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|title=Top Palestinians arrive in Paris 'Apologize'|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3991153.stm |publisher=BBC|date=8 November 2004|accessdate=11 October 2007}}</ref>
The next day, chief surgeon Christian Estripeau of Percy reported that Arafat's condition had worsened, and that he had fallen into a deeper coma.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2004-11/07/content_2187955.htm|title=Arafat's health unchanged: French official|date=7 November 2004|publisher=Xinhua}}</ref> [[Sheikh Taissir Tamimi]], the head of the Islamic court of the Palestinian territories, who held a vigil at Arafat's bedside, visited Arafat, and declared that it was out of the question to disconnect him from [[life support]], since, according to him, such an action is prohibited in Islam.<ref name="Arafat Timeline">{{cite web|url=http://www.passia.org/Arafat/Arafat.pdf|format=PDF|title=Yasser Arafat (1929–2004)|date=11 December 2004|publisher=PASSIA|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229043817/http://www.passia.org/Arafat/Arafat.pdf|archivedate=29 February 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Death== [[File:Mausoleo Arafat (Muqata, Ramallah) 02.JPG|thumb|right|Arafat mausoleum]]
Arafat was pronounced incapacitated on 11 November 2004 at 03:30 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]] at the age of 75 of what French doctors called a massive haemorrhagic [[cerebrovascular accident]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://s3.documentcloud.org/documents/393851/hospitalization-report-english.pdf |title=Hospitalization|publisher=D Cloud|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref><ref name=AP-exhume>{{cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/palestinians-ready-exhume-arafat-body-tests |title=New tests revive debate over Arafat death |publisher=Associated Press|date=4 July 2012|accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref> However, the underlying infection was declared unknown.<ref name=NYT>{{cite news|title=Medical records say Arafat died from a stroke|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/08/international/middleeast/08arafat.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=8 September 2005|author=Steven Erlanger|author2=Lawrence K. Altman}}</ref> The official statement announcing his death failed to determine a cause, saying only that he had a "mystery blood disorder".<ref name=KRTSMH>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/11/12/1100131178126.html?from=storylhs|title=Arafat's doctor calls for autopsy|date=12 November 2004|work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref>
The ''[[Le Canard enchaîné|Canard Enchaîné]]'' newspaper reported alleged leaks of information by unnamed medical sources at Percy hospital that had access to Arafat and his medical file. According to the newspaper, the doctors at Percy hospital suspected, from Arafat's arrival, grave lesions of the liver responsible for an alteration of the composition of the blood; Arafat was therefore placed in a [[hematology]] service. [[Leukemia]] was "soundly ruled out". According to the same source, the reason why this diagnosis of [[cirrhosis]] could not be made available was that, in the mind of the general public, cirrhosis is generally associated with the consequences of alcohol abuse. Even though the diagnosis was not of alcoholic cirrhosis and Arafat was not known for consuming any alcohol, there was a likelihood of rumors. The source explained that Arafat's living conditions did little to improve the situation. Thus, according to the source, the probable causes of the disease were multiple; Arafat's coma was a consequence of the worsened cirrhosis. The French newspaper ''[[Le Monde]]'' quoted doctors as saying that he suffered from "an unusual blood disease and a liver problem".<ref>{{cite news|title=Palestinians head to Paris to probe Arafat's death |url=http://www.despardes.com/oscartango/111704.html |work=Oscar-Tango |publisher=Despardes Inc. |date=17 November 2004 |accessdate=26 September 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070404023909/http://www.despardes.com/oscartango/111704.html |archivedate=4 April 2007 }}</ref>
After Arafat's death, the [[Minister of Defence (France)|French Ministry of Defence]] said that Arafat's medical file would be transmitted to only his [[next of kin]]. It was determined that Arafat's nephew and PNA envoy to the UN, [[Nasser al-Qudwa]], was a close enough relative, thus working around Suha Arafat's silence on her husband's illness. Nasser al-Qudwa was given a copy of Arafat's 558-page medical file by the French Ministry of Defence.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arafat doctors found 'no poison':Tests on Yasser Arafat's body showed no traces of any known poisons, according to medical files released on Monday. |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4032257.stm|publisher=BBC News|date=22 November 2004|accessdate=2 September 2007}}</ref>
==Theories about the cause of death== [[File:Yasser Arafat's tombstone.jpg|thumb|right|Palestinian honor guard stationed at Arafat's temporary tomb in Ramallah]] There are numerous theories about the cause of Arafat's death. Initially Arafat records were withheld by senior Palestinian officials. In 2004, Palestinian Foreign Minister Nabil Shaath has said after talks with Arafat's French doctors that they had "ruled out completely poison". However, Shaath recently stated in "The Price of Kings", a documentary on Arafat's leadership, "I have no doubt that he was assassinated. The French said that whatever toxic material was in his body did not test positive in their toxicology table, saying in plain words "this was a poison we did not have in our laboratories."<ref>https://www.spiritlevelfilm.com/thepriceofkings/landingb/ {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130601032941/http://www.spiritlevelfilm.com/thepriceofkings/landingb/# |date=1 June 2013 }}{{full citation needed|date=February 2017}}</ref>
Al-Kurdi, Arafat's personal physician for 18 years, said "I would usually be summoned to attend to Arafat immediately, even when all he had was a simple cold ... But when his medical situation was really deteriorating, they chose not to call me at all", and Arafat's wife, Suha, refused to allow him to visit Arafat in the private Paris hospital where he was being treated. Later he was denied access to Arafat's body after his death.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rubinstein|first=Danny|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/arafat-s-doctor-there-was-hiv-in-his-blood-but-poison-killed-him-1.227303|title=Arafat's doctor: There was HIV in his blood, but poison killed him |publisher=Haaretz|date=12 August 2007|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref>
Al-Kurdi also lamented that Arafat's widow Suha had refused an autopsy, which he said would have answered many questions regarding cause of death.<ref name="Al-Kurdi Claims">{{cite news|first=Danny|last=Rubenstein|authorlink=Danny Rubenstein |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/pages/ShArt.jhtml?itemNo=892231&contrassID=1&subContrassID=1|title=Arafat's doctor: There was HIV in his blood, but poison killed him|date=8 September 2005|work=Haaretz}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Steven|last=Erlanger|author2=Lawrence K. Altman|title=Medical Records Say Arafat Died From a Stroke |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/08/international/middleeast/08arafat.html?n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes%20Topics%2FSubjects%2FP%2FPoisoning%20and%20Poisons&pagewanted=print|work=The New York Times|date=8 September 2005|accessdate=26 September 2007 }}</ref>
Medical records released in 2005 showed that Arafat's doctors could not agree on the cause of death, stating that he died from a stroke that stemmed from an unknown condition. Analysis based on those records suggested him dying from poisoning, AIDS, or an infection.<ref name="AIDS"/><ref name="MSNBC">{{cite news|title=Arafat's doctor wants autopsy|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/6472056/ |agency=Associated Press|date=12 November 2004|accessdate=12 December 2007}}</ref> In 2012, newly released medical records revealed that French doctors initially diagnosed Arafat with gastroenteritis.<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite news|title=Yasser Arafat medical records show health was blamed on gastroenteritis|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/palestinianauthority/9396397/Yasser-Arafat-medical-records-show-health-was-blamed-on-gastroenteritis.html|accessdate=12 July 2012|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=12 July 2012}}</ref>
===AIDS=== In September 2005, based on obtained Arafat records, an Israeli [[HIV/AIDS|AIDS]] expert claimed that Arafat bore all the symptoms of AIDS, while ''[[The New York Times]]'' claimed it was highly unlikely that Arafat died from AIDS.<ref name="AIDS">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/4225332.stm |title=Cause of Arafat death 'unknown' Medical records of former Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat appear to show that doctors could not determine the underlying cause of his death|date=8 September 2005 |publisher=BBC News}}</ref> [[John Loftus (author)|John Loftus]] reported on ABC radio that Arafat had died of AIDS. According to Loftus, the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] had knowledge of his condition, and convinced Israel not to assassinate him and wait for his inevitable death of the disease, since the subsequent widespread connotations of the disease with homosexuality would discredit him.<ref name=McDermott>{{Cite book|title=Presidential leadership, illness, and decision making|last=McDermott|first=Rose|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2008|isbn=978-0-521-88272-9|page=244|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> Arafat's personal doctor for 18 years, Dr. Ashraf Al-Kurdi, said Arafat suffered from AIDS.<ref>{{cite news|title=palestinian arafat died of H.I.V (AIDS), DR al-kurdi. أبو عمار|website=[[YouTube]]|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZCoW7Sagti8}}</ref>
However an article published in a number of American news publications rejected the assertion that Arafat had AIDS, stating, "An Israeli infectious disease specialist said he would have performed the test, if only to be thorough and to refute the rumors that surrounded the case. He said news accounts during Arafat's illness made him strongly suspect that Arafat had AIDS. But after studying the records, he said that was improbable, given the sudden onset of the intestinal troubles", though AIDS-associated opportunistic infections such as [[cryptosporidiosis]] can begin in this way. This same article also states that it is "highly unlikely" that Arafat had died from poisoning, and further asserts that Arafat had died from a stroke linked to an "underlying infection."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.sfgate.com/2005-09-08/news/17388635_1_medical-records-percy-army-teaching-hospital-unexplained-death-last-year|work=The San Francisco Chronicle|title=Best Books Of 2003|first1=Steven|last1=Erlanger|first2=Lawrence K.|last2=Altman|date=8 September 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/09/08/international/middleeast/08arafat.html?_r=2&n=Top%2FReference%2FTimes%20Topics%2FSubjects%2FP%2FPoisoning%20and%20Poisons&pagewanted=print|work=The New York Times| title=Medical Records Say Arafat Died From a Stroke|first1=Steven|last1=Erlanger|first2=Lawrence K.|last2=Altman|date=8 September 2005}}</ref>
===High-tech laser=== In 2005, Palestinian ambassador to [[Sri Lanka]] Attalah Quiba alleged that Arafat was killed by two Israelis with a high-tech [[laser]], and the two Israelis attempted to flee but were "wrestled down by Palestinian Security personnel". Quiba also alleged that 16 countries had tested the blood of Arafat, and determined that Arafat was poisoned through "high technology".<ref name="Fox 35">{{cite web| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,151209,00.html|title=An End to the 35-hour French Workweek|publisher=Fox News Channel|date=22 March 2005|accessdate=20 September 2012|author=Levine, Michael}}</ref>
===Gastroenteritis=== New medical records that were released in July 2012 showed that Arafat's condition was initially diagnosed as viral [[gastroenteritis]] by his Arab doctors who took care of him in the [[West Bank]] in the [[Mukataa]] before he was airlifted to France, although his condition later improved and he even joined in the fast of [[Ramadan]]. However, there was persistent vomiting and diarrhea, Arafat began feeling weaker, and his blood platelet count dropped. On 28 October, his medical team decided to send him abroad, and he was flown to France the next morning.<ref name="TelegraphGastro">{{cite web| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/palestinianauthority/9396397/Yasser-Arafat-medical-records-show-health-was-blamed-on-gastroenteritis.html|title=Yasser Arafat medical records show health was blamed on gastroenteritis|work=The Telegraph|date=12 July 2012| accessdate=15 July 2012}}</ref><ref name="APGastro">{{cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g1ple-ADLrr_vMRu6EP5Lyzm4XXw?docId=8b152bbe62d3498da9b15012fcaf6c56|title=New Arafat medical file released in death probe|agency=Associated Press |date=12 July 2012|accessdate=15 July 2012|author=Laub, Karin}}</ref>
Dr Joseph Zimmerman, an Israeli specialist who reviewed the Ramallah medical file said Arafat's early symptoms were not consistent with viral gastroenteritis, and did not believe that type of viral infection would lead to death. He also said that poisoning appeared unlikely, even by a radioactive substance such as polonium-210. He reminded people that Arafat's platelet counts dropped suddenly and stayed low, and that Arafat eventually exhibited signs of liver dysfunction, which could have been caused by a bacterial infection, but is not typical of poisoning.<ref name="TelegraphGastro"/><ref name="APGastro"/>
===Platelet disorder=== A report by the French doctors who treated him states that a [[platelet]] disorder caused Arafat's death. The cause of this platelet disorder is unknown, although poison is a possibility.<ref>{{cite news|title=Family: Platelet disorder killed Arafat|url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=435849|agency=[[Ma'an News Agency]]|date=11 October 2011|accessdate=4 July 2012}}</ref>
===Poisoning=== In 2004, Palestinian Foreign Minister Nabil Shaath said after talks with Arafat's French doctors that they had "ruled out completely poison".<ref name="MSNBC"/> A 2005 article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' said that based on his records it was highly unlikely that Arafat died from poisoning.<ref name="AIDS"/> Meanwhile, al-Kurdi called for the creation of an independent commission to carry out investigations concerning Arafat's suspicious death, stating, "any doctor would tell you that these are the symptoms of a poisoning".<ref name="Al-Kurdi Claims"/><ref>{{cite news|first=Amnon|last=Kapeliouk|title=Yasser Arafat a-t-il été assassiné? ("Was Arafat murdered?") |url=http://www.monde-diplomatique.fr/2005/11/KAPELIOUK/12894?var_recherche=arafat|work=Le Monde diplomatique|date=2 November 2005 |accessdate=21 July 2007|language= French}}</ref>
Former Knesset member, peace activist and personal friend of Arafat [[Uri Avnery]] claimed at the time of Arafat's death that he had been poisoned, and repeated the claim in 2012.<ref>[[Uri Avnery]],[http://www.counterpunch.org/2012/07/06/poisoning-arafat/ Poisoning Arafat], at [[CounterPunch]], 6–8 July 2012.</ref> Another "senior Israeli physician" claimed in an article in ''[[Haaretz]]'' that it was "a classic case of food poisoning", probably caused by a meal eaten four hours before he fell ill that may have contained a toxin such as [[ricin]], rather than a standard bacterial poisoning. However, in the same week as the report in ''Haaretz'', ''The New York Times'' published a separate report, also based on access to Arafat's medical records, which claimed that it was highly unlikely that Arafat had [[Foodborne illness|food poisoning]].<ref name="AIDS"/><ref name="MSNBC"/>
====Poisoning with thallium==== In 2009, [[Bassam Abu Sharif]], Arafat's former advisor, alleged that [[Mossad]], the national intelligence agency of Israel, had poisoned Arafat by a lethal dose of [[Thallium poisoning|thallium]],<ref>[http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=349911 ''Arafat's aide: New information on president's death''], Ma'an News Agency, 10 January 2011.</ref> a rare chemical whose effects are difficult to trace,<ref name="AA"/> via Arafat's daily medications. Abu Sharif alleged that the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF) had held the driver of a Palestinian ambulance that brought him his medications, for a minimum of 30 minutes while the IDF searched it. According to Abu Sharif, this incident would have allowed Israel to replace Arafat's medications with poison.<ref name="Bassam Abu Sharif's claim about poisoning">{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2009/July/21%20n/Israeli%20Mossad%20poisoned%20Arafat%20through%20his%20medications,%20says%20Bassam%20Abu%20Sharif.htm |title=Israeli Mossad poisoned Arafat through his medications|date=22 July 2009|work=Al-Jazeerah}}</ref> In his book ''Arafat and the Dream of Palestine: An Insider's Account'', Abu Sarif wrote, "I was positive they were poisoning his food on a daily basis and doing it right under our very eyes."<ref name="Abu Sharif">{{cite book|title=Arafat and the Dream of Palestine: An Insider's Account|publisher=Macmillan|author=Abu Sharif, Bassam|year=2009|page=251|isbn=0230608019}}</ref>
In 2011, Abu Sarif alleged that an investigation conducted by "the most prominent forensic toxicology expert in the UK" had revealed that thallium was responsible for poisoning Arafat. According to Abu Sharif, European toxicology experts are not familiar with thallium and only this forensic toxicology expert could have identified the thallium. However, Abu Sharif did not reveal the names of the expert or the institution responsible for the research.<ref name="AA">{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/01/11/133028.html| title=Arafat death caused by rare poison: top adviser|publisher=Al Arabiya|date=11 January 2011|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref>
As a result of Abu Sharif's allegations, the delegates at the August 2009 Fatah convention in [[Bethlehem]] voted for a resolution which blamed Israel for poisoning Yasser Arafat. An editorial in ''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' questioned the legitimacy of Abu Sharif's allegations, noting that "nobody asked how Abu Sharif came to possess this information, whether he can back it up or why he chose to divulge it so late".<ref name="JPost edit">{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Editorials/Article.aspx?id=276287|title=Arafat's death|work=The Jerusalem Post|date=4 July 2012|accessdate=20 September 2012}}</ref> A leader of Fatah and a nephew of Arafat said that an investigation indicated a "high possibility of poisoning" but that there was not any proof.<ref name="NYT fatah">{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/11/world/middleeast/11fatah.html?_r=0|title=Fatah Turns to Nation Building, Though It Doesn't Discard the Rifle|work=The New York Times|date=10 August 2009|accessdate=20 September 2012|author=Kershner, Isabel}}</ref>
====Poisoning with polonium==== According to Israel Radio, a former Palestinian intelligence officer, attorney Fahmi Shabana, said that Yasser Arafat's political rivals were responsible for his death, and that he was poisoned with [[polonium]]. Shabana, who took part in the investigation into Arafat's death in a French hospital in 2004, also said that several months after his death, the same cell murdered the head of military intelligence in [[Gaza City|Gaza]], General [[Moussa Arafat]], a relative of the PLO leader, in order to prevent a blood feud. The lawyer called on Palestinian Authority president [[Mahmoud Abbas]] to reopen the investigation into Arafat's death."<ref>[[Kol Yisrael]] English news, 17 January 2011, 0430 [[Coordinated Universal Time|UTC]]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/news/pages/676ce5b7-f085-45d4-9c97-5c7a32864c06|title=الأخبار - ضابط فلسطيني: خصوم عرفات قتلوه عربي|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=17 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref>
On ''[[Newsnight]]'' on UK TV on 21 January 2016, during a feature on the 2006 assassination of [[Alexander Litvinienko]], [[George Galloway]] claimed to have been with Yasser Arafat in Paris when he died of polonium-210 poisoning.<ref>{{cite episode |title=George Galloway and Alex Goldfarb on Litvinenko inquiry |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=H0om8ii5XVs&t=113 |series=[[Newsnight]] |network=[[BBC Television|BBC]] |date=21 January 2016 |time=1:53 |access-date=28 March 2018}}</ref>
=====Al Jazeera's investigation===== On 4 July 2012, [[Al Jazeera]] reported that a nine-month investigation by Al Jazeera had revealed that none of the causes of Arafat's death suggested in several rumors were true, as Arafat was in good health until he suddenly fell ill on 12 October 2004. Tests carried out by the ''Institut de Radiophysique'' (Institute of Radiation Physics) at the [[University of Lausanne]] in [[Switzerland]] found traces of polonium, a rare, highly [[radioactive decay|radioactive]] element, on Arafat's personal belongings, which suggested that there was a high level of polonium inside his body when he died. The lethal element was found in quantities much higher than could occur naturally, and further, that 60%–80% of that polonium (depending on the item being tested) had not come from natural sources.<ref name=AJ_widow_calls>[http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/whatkilledarafat/2012/07/20127383653774794.html "Arafat's widow calls for body to be exhumed"]. Gregg Carlstrom, Al Jazeera, 4 July 2012</ref><ref name=BBC_call_for_inquiry>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-18695634 "Yasser Arafat: Palestinians call for poison inquiry"]. BBC, 4 July 2012</ref>
In October 2010, an official press release from the Institut de Radiophysique, where those items were analyzed, had stated that: <blockquote>"an unexplained quantity of Polonium-210 has been detected on the personal effects of Mr. Arafat. However, this is not sufficient to determine the causes of death. In particular, it will be recalled that, contrary to what happened in the case of the former Russian spy [[Alexander Litvinenko]], Mr. Arafat did not lose his hair, and some of the findings in the forensic report are inconsistent with an acute radiation syndrome."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chuv.ch/ira/ira_home/actu-xml-list/actueve_detail.htm?id=3278 |title=Institut de radiophysique |publisher=[[University Hospital of Lausanne|University Hospital of Lausanne (CHUV)]] |date=14 October 2010 |accessdate=28 January 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130118203653/http://www.chuv.ch/ira/ira_home/actu-xml-list/actueve_detail.htm?id=3278 |archivedate=18 January 2013 }}</ref></blockquote>
In July 2012, a spokesman for the Institut de Radiophysique stressed that the "clinical symptoms described in Arafat's medical reports were not consistent with polonium-210 and that conclusions could not be drawn as to whether the Palestinian leader was poisoned or not", and that "the only way to confirm the findings would be to exhume Arafat's body to test it for polonium-210".<ref>{{cite news|last=Bart|first=Katharina|date=3 July 2012|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/07/03/us-palestinians-arafat-idUSBRE8621CL20120703|title=Swiss institute finds polonium in Arafat's effects|agency=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Arafat poisoned by polonium: report|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gC3BrMO_aYwFIwTAtXLsWoQnAing?docId=CNG.b427100ac45d92b76358ffa0029eb52a.261|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=2 July 2012|accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> François Bochud, who heads the Institute of Radiation Physics in Lausanne, Switzerland, stated that "our results are clearly not a proof of any poisoning".<ref name=AP-exhume/> Alastair Hay, professor of environmental toxicology at the University of Leeds in England, stated: "You don't know much about the provenance of the clothing and whether it had been tampered with later on. You'd want to test the body."<ref name=AP-exhume/>
In response to Al Jazeera's report, Dr [[Ely Karmon]], at [[International Institute for Counter-Terrorism|Herzliya's Institute for Counterterrorism]], a specialist in chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear terrorism, said that "the half-life of the substance [i.e., slightly more than 138 days 9 hours] would make it impossible for polonium to have been discovered at such high levels if it had been used to kill Arafat eight years ago. If it had been used for poisoning, minimal levels should be seen now. Yet much higher levels were found. Someone planted the polonium much later." He went on to question why Arafat's widow, Suha Arafat, who provided the researchers with Arafat's belongings was not also poisoned while she was by his side at the hospital touching him and his clothing.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=276447 Polonium found on Arafat's clothing was planted], ''The Jerusalem Post'', 5 July 2012</ref>
Israel has denied any connection to the rumours. Deputy Spokesman of [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Israel)|Israeli Foreign Ministry]] Paul Hirschson was skeptical of the rumours, joking, "All of a sudden, Suha's checking her wash basket and discovered clothes that weren't washed for eight years. Suddenly, out of nowhere a couple of garments turn up; we test them, and presto! There's Polonium." Avi Dichter, who was in charge of the Shin Bet when Arafat died, told Army radio that "Yasser Arafat had many enemies, domestically, abroad. But let them investigate. ... The Palestinians know well how to investigate what goes on in their house. Let them investigate and find out."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-07/05/c_131697980.htm|title=Israeli officials deny Arafat poisoning rumors|publisher=Xinhua|date=5 July 2012}}</ref>
On 12 October 2013, the British medical journal ''[[The Lancet]]'' published a peer-reviewed article titled "Improving forensic investigation for polonium poisoning".<ref name=pmid24120205/> In the article, a group of Swiss doctors suggested that Arafat could have died of polonium poisoning. The team analysed 38 samples of Arafat's clothes and belongings and 37 reference samples which were known to be polonium-free. Several of the Arafat samples were notably more radioactive than the controls, but not all. The team believed that an autopsy could be useful in this case. After testing Arafat's personal belongings and samples of his body fluids, the chief of the Federal Medical-Biological Agency of Russia, Vladimir Uiba, concluded that polonium was not the cause of his death,<ref name="ansamed.info">http://www.ansamed.info/ansamed/en/news/sections/generalnews/2013/10/15/Arafat-Russia-rules-death-caused-polonium-poisoning_9462946.html{{full citation needed|date=February 2017}}</ref> but the Agency then denied that Uiba's comments were official.<ref name=Reuters_Arafat_poisoned>[http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/1.556656 "Swiss team: Arafat poisoned to death with polonium"]. Reuters/''Haaretz'', 6 November 2013</ref> British forensic scientist Professor David Barclay said the Swiss team's findings were a "smoking gun", and that it was "absolutely certain" that polonium had been the cause of his death.<ref name=Reuters_Arafat_poisoned/><ref>{{cite news |title=Yasser Arafat: Tests 'Support' Polonium Claims |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1164820/yasser-arafat-tests-support-polonium-claims |accessdate=6 November 2013 |publisher=[[Sky News]] |date=6 November 2013}}</ref> After the results of the French and Russian tests became public, David Barclay did not comment or communicate any more on the case.
The French tests found some polonium but stated it was from "natural environmental origin".<ref name="wtop.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.wtop.com/220/3531404/Russia-Arafats-death-not-caused-by-radiation |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-12-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131230234655/http://www.wtop.com/220/3531404/Russia-Arafats-death-not-caused-by-radiation |archivedate=30 December 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> Later the Russian tests released in December 2013 found that Arafat's death was not caused by radiation. [[Vladimir Uiba]], the head of the Russian Federal Medical and Biological Agency, stated that Yasser had died of natural causes and they had no plans to conduct further tests.<ref name="wtop.com"/>
=====Call for new investigation=====
Following Al Jazeera's revelations, [[Suha Arafat]], Arafat's widow, called for the exhumation of Arafat's body for further testing, in response to the [[Al Jazeera]] story about [[polonium]].<ref name=AJ_widow_calls/> In response, Abbas ordered a committee to be formed, and stated that there were no religious or political obstacles to exhuming the body.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.wafa.ps/index.php?action=detail&id=20203|title=WAFA - Abbas Orders Committee to Investigate Arafat's Death|access-date=12 July 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112134732/http://english.wafa.ps/index.php?action=detail&id=20203#|archive-date=12 November 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, Nimr Hamad, an aide to Abbas, stated that a team of experts would first be sent to [[Europe]] to learn more from the Swiss institute and from the French military hospital where Arafat died. Abbas stated that he would only order an autopsy if the family agreed, but did not define whom in the family he meant.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/aide-palestinian-leader-arafat-16715648 |title=International News|publisher=ABC|date=24 January 2013}}</ref> Later, Abbas stated that they would only investigate "if necessary".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/Health/Article.aspx?id=276549|title=Abbas: We'll open new Arafat probe|publisher=JPost|date=11 November 2004}}</ref> Tawfiq Tirawi, the head of the committee in charge of investigating Arafat's death, stated: "We are certain that there are Palestinian hands that contributed to the elimination of Yasser Arafat." With regards to those people, Tirawi stated that they "will be subject to severe penalties and doomed to death".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palpress.co.uk/arabic/?action=detail&id=54114|title=وكالة فلسطين برس للأنباء|publisher=Palpress}}</ref> On 30 July 2012, Tirawi added, "We haven't initiated the investigation based on the hypothesis that Arafat was killed by poison, but we agreed to begin an investigation searching directly for the killer regardless of the medical reports which will eventually show the method of killing and name of the toxin."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.maannews.net/eng/ViewDetails.aspx?ID=508459|title=Arafat inquiry like looking for 'needle in the ocean'|publisher=MAAN|accessdate=28 January 2013}}</ref>
Tunisia also requested that the [[Arab League]] convene a ministerial meeting to discuss Arafat's death and study the circumstances in which he died.<ref>{{cite news|last=Harel|first=Amos |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/middle-east/tunisia-requests-arab-league-meeting-over-suspicions-arafat-murdered-1.449067|title=Tunisia requests Arab League meeting over suspicions Arafat murdered|publisher=Haaretz|date=5 July 2012}}</ref>
Arab League Secretary-General [[Nabil Elaraby]] stated that a permanent representative meeting would be held to discuss Arafat's death, and that permanent representatives would prepare a report and raise proposals over necessary action, which they would present in the soonest Arab League ministerial meeting.<ref name="aljazeera">{{cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2012/07/2012710211321389670.html|title=Arafat's widow seeks French probe into death |publisher=Al Jazeera|date=10 July 2012}}</ref>
==Exhumation of Arafat's remains== On 9 July 2012, Palestinian Authority President [[Mahmoud Abbas]] approved the exhumation of Arafat's body in response to the [[Al Jazeera]] story about [[polonium]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Khadder|first=Kareem|title=Palestinian leader signs off on Arafat exhumation, PLO official says|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/07/09/world/meast/mideast-arafat-exhumation/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=9 July 2012}}</ref> On 8 August 2012, Swiss experts were invited to the West Bank to prepare for the examination of Yasser Arafat's remains to investigate possible poisoning.<ref>{{cite web|last=Daraghmeh|first=Mohammed|title=Swiss experts invited to conduct Arafat Autopsy|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/A/ARAFATS_DEATH?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2012-08-08-12-29-45|agency=Associated Press|accessdate=8 August 2012}}</ref> The lab said that they wanted guarantees that the investigation would not be used for political purposes, saying, "Meanwhile, our main concern is to guarantee the independence, the credibility and the transparency of any involvement that we may have."<ref name="Lab politics">{{cite news|url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=280602|title=Swiss lab wants guarantee in Arafat death inquiry|work=The Jerusalem Post|agency=Reuters|date=9 August 2012|accessdate=9 August 2012}}</ref> On 27 November 2012, three teams of international investigators collected samples from Arafat's body and the surrounding soil in the mausoleum in [[Ramallah]]. A French, a Swiss and a Russian team have independently investigated the samples.<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2012/11/2012112795443645353.html "Yasser Arafat's body exhumed in Ramallah"]. Gregg Carlstrom, Al Jazeera, 27 November 2012</ref><ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-202_162-57554606/yasser-arafats-remains-exhumed-for-death-investigation-palestinians-say/ "Yasser Arafat's remains exhumed for death investigation, Palestinians say"]. CBS, 27 November 2012</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Experts exhume Arafat, seek evidence of poison|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/11/27/us-palestinians-arafat-idUSBRE8AP1A120121127|agency=Reuters|accessdate=27 November 2012}}</ref>
Publication of the results of the studies was delayed, reportedly on the request of the Palestinian Authority, which feared they could have negative impact on the peace talks.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Middle-East/Experts-late-with-test-results-in-Arafat-death-case-327627 "Experts late with test results in Arafat death case"]. Khaled abu Toameh, ''Jerusalem Post'', 2 October 2013</ref>
On 6 November 2013, Al Jazeera reported that the Swiss forensic team had found levels of polonium in Arafat's ribs and pelvis 18 times higher than normal, and were 83% confident that polonium poisoning had occurred, but Professor Bochud disagreed with this interpretation by Al Jazeera and only stated that the poisoning hypothesis by polonium was "moderately supported".<ref>http://www.aljazeera.com/investigations/killing-arafat/qa-francois-bochud-arafat-report-2013117184743478799.html{{full citation needed|date=February 2017}}</ref>
According to a journalist from the Swiss daily newspaper [[Le Temps]], Luis Lema, the Swiss experts had concluded that on a probability scale ranging from one to six, death by polonium poisoning was around five <ref name=LT24.05.14/>.
Arafat's widow Suha stated her belief that he was a victim of a "political assassination" but refrained from finger-pointing and said she would await the French forensic results.<ref name=Reuters_Arafat_poisoned/><ref name=Guardianpolonium>Angelique Chrisafis, Harriet Sherwood,[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/06/yasser-arafat-poisoned-polonium-tests-scientists'Yasser Arafat may have been poisoned with polonium, tests show,'] ''The Guardian'', 6 November 2013.</ref><ref>David Poort and Ken Silverstein,[http://www.aljazeera.com/investigations/killing-arafat/swiss-study-polonium-found-arafats-bones-201311522578803512.html 'Swiss study: Polonium found in Arafat's bones,'] al-Jazeera, 6 November 2013.</ref>
[[Joods Actueel]], a Belgian monthly newspaper, claimed that most experts in forensics disagreed that the results were consistent with polonium poisoning and that the conclusions of the Swiss study were not in line with the results obtained.<ref>[http://joodsactueel.be/2013/11/19/deskundigen-maken-brandhout-van-zwitsers-rapport-na-vraag-belgische-onderzoeker/ Is the "Arafat was poisoned" hypothesis "moderately" supported by the Swiss report, "strongly wrong"?]</ref>
Forensic biologist Nathan Lents of the [[John Jay College of Criminal Justice]] said the report's results were consistent with a possible polonium poisoning, but "There's certainly not a smoking gun here."
Derek Hill, a professor in radiological science at [[University College London]] who was not involved in the investigation, said: "I would say it's clearly not overwhelming proof, and there is a risk of contamination (of the samples), but it is a pretty strong signal. ... It seems likely what they're doing is putting a very cautious interpretation of strong data."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/al-jazeera-reports-evidence-arafat-poisoning |title=Possible evidence of Arafat poisoning is reported |publisher=Associated Press|date=6 November 2013|accessdate=27 December 2014}}</ref>
After the testing of Arafat's remains by the Russian team, the Russian Medical-Biological Agency concluded that polonium was not the cause of his death.<ref name="ansamed.info"/> However, the government scientific body later denied that it had made any official statement about the research, saying only that it had handed its results to the Russian Foreign Ministry.<ref>[http://news.msn.com/world/russian-official-rules-out-arafat-polonium-poisoning?ocid=msnnws Arafat: Russia rules out death caused by polonium poisoning]. ANSA, 15 October 2013</ref> However, Al Jazeera found that the Russian scientists had only investigated four out of 20 samples, being the samples that were unlikely to show the amount of radioactive exposure. The scientists also appear to have been restricted by the Russian Foreign Ministry in how to present the report. According to Al Jazeera's source, "Russia's goal was to fulfill the Palestinian Authority's request, not offend Israel by helping the PA, and not create a new hotbed in the Middle East".<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/investigations/killing-arafat/experts-question-russian-arafat-findings-2013118102237239238.html "Experts question Russian Arafat findings"], Al Jazeera, 8 November 2013.</ref>
In December 2013, an unidentified person leaked what were claimed to be the results of the French investigation to [[Agence France-Presse|AFP]], saying that "the report rules out the poisoning theory and goes in the sense of a natural death".<ref name="afp-leak">{{cite news|url=http://www.afp.com/en/news/topstories/arafat-was-not-poisoned-say-french-experts|title=Arafat 'was not poisoned' say French experts|date=2013-12-03|agency=AFP|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131204022408/http://www.afp.com/en/news/topstories/arafat-was-not-poisoned-say-french-experts|archivedate=2013-12-04}}</ref> According to the leaker, the report says Arafat died of a "generalised infection".<ref name="bbc-leak">{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-25205170|title=Yasser Arafat 'was not poisoned' - leaked French report|publisher=BBC News|date=2013-12-03|author=Fraser, Christian|accessdate=2013-12-04|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203180722/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-25205170|archivedate=2013-12-03}}</ref> On December 4, Al Jazeera quoted Suha Arafat speaking at a press conference after having received the French report: "Is it the poisoned body that would have contaminated the environment outside? Or is it the opposite? The first one is the conclusion of the Swiss. The Swiss think that the body was poisoned and contaminated the environment. And the French reach the opposite conclusion—that it's actually the environment outside which explains the presence of polonium 210."<ref>[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/europe/2013/12/french-experts-rule-out-arafat-poisoning-2013123145211499109.html Al Jazeera: French Experts Rule Out Arafat Poisoning]</ref> Later that same month, a Russian investigative team from the Federal Medico-Biological Agency agreed that Arafat did not die from poisoning.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2013/12/26/world/europe/26reuters-arafat-death-russia.html|title=Russia Says Arafat Died of Natural Causes: Interfax|date=26 December 2013|work=New York Times|agency=Reuters|accessdate=26 December 2013}}</ref>
Unlike the Swiss report, the French and Russian reports were not made public, at the time.<ref name=LT24.05.14>{{fr}} Luis Lema, [http://www.letemps.ch/Page/Uuid/afa176fe-e2a3-11e3-a6a0-66e041ce382a/Yasser_Arafat_la_valse_des_isotopes "Yasser Arafat, la valse des isotopes"], ''[[Le Temps]]'', Saturday 24 May 2014, p. 3.</ref> The French later announced that foul play was not involved.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/mar/16/yasser-arafat-french-rule-out-foul-play Yasser Arafat: French rule out foul play in former Palestinian leader's death]</ref>
The [[Lausanne University Hospital|CHUV]] published in February 2016 a paper in [[Science Direct]] to justify their conclusions. They admitted: "The evidences gathered during this expert report are not clear-cut: we cannot exclude <sup>210</sup>Po as a cause of death, but we cannot be sure that <sup>210</sup>Po was the cause of death."<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/j.forsciint.2015.09.019 |pmid=26707208 |title=210Po poisoning as possible cause of death: Forensic investigations and toxicological analysis of the remains of Yasser Arafat |journal=Forensic Science International |volume=259 |pages=1–9 |year=2016 |last1=Froidevaux |first1=Pascal |last2=Bochud |first2=François |last3=Baechler |first3=Sébastien |last4=Castella |first4=Vincent |last5=Augsburger |first5=Marc |last6=Bailat |first6=Claude |last7=Michaud |first7=Katarzyna |last8=Straub |first8=Marietta |last9=Pecchia |first9=Marco |last10=Jenk |first10=Theo M. |last11=Uldin |first11=Tanya |last12=Mangin |first12=Patrice }}</ref> In an other document the CHUV explains "...these results do not then define the probability to which Yasser Arafat would have been poisoned by polonium, but must be integrated into the larger context of the police and legal investigations in connection to this case, and which are beyond our field of expertise" which shows several press articles using probability figures were completerly wrong in interpreting the results.<ref>[https://archive.is/20161204184407/http://www.chuv.ch/ira/ira-arafat-faq.pdf Page 1 Frequently asked questions regarding the expertise conducted on President Yasser Arafat's personal belongings and remains] Lausanne, 15 December 2015 (corrected version of 15 February 2016)</ref>
Joods Actueel publishes in July 2016 an updated document whereby it states that their previous analysis was confirmed by CHUV. According to them, the conclusions that are based only on [[Bayes' theorem|Bayes analysis]] are not valid as they are not documented with figures.<ref>[http://joodsactueel.be/wp-content/uploads-pjact001/2016/06/2_PDFsam_20160702-chuv-arafat-no-proof.pdf Two years after, the CHUV (Swiss scientists) admits no proof of Arafat's poisoning.]</ref> It also reminds juridical errors based on such method as the case of [[Sally Clark]].
==Murder inquiry==
After Al Jazeera's presentation in July 2012 of the results of its nine-month investigation, Arafat's widow [[Suha Arafat]] declared her intention to launch a court case in France into the death of her husband.<ref>[http://www.nydailynews.com/news/world/yasser-arafat-widow-seeks-french-probe-death-poisoning-probe-article-1.1111556 ''Yasser Arafat's widow seeks French probe of his death amid poisoning probe'']. Associated Press, 10 July 2012</ref> Suha Arafat told Al Jazeera that she had long suspected that her former husband was murdered, noting that both Israel and the United States regarded him as an obstacle to peace.<ref name="aljazeera"/>
On 31 July 2012, Suha Arafat and her daughter Zawra lodged a murder complaint in the Paris western suburb of Nanterre. On 28 August, French prosecutors opened a murder inquiry.<ref>[http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/france-opens-arafat-murder-enquiry-sources-.aspx?pageID=238&nID=28856&NewsCatID=351 France opens Arafat murder enquiry: sources]. AFP, 28 August 2012</ref> In March 2015, a French prosecutor announced that Arafat's death was from natural causes, and found that the polonium 210 and lead 210 discovered in Arafat's grave were of an environmental nature.<ref>{{cite news|title=French Experts Say No Foul Play in Arafat Death|url=http://www.naharnet.com/stories/en/171773-french-experts-say-no-foul-play-in-arafat-death|accessdate=17 March 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://www.jpost.com/Arab-Israeli-Conflict/Arafat-was-not-poisoned-French-prosecutor-says-394173 Arafat was not poisoned, French prosecutor says]</ref>
Later, a French investigation by three judges unanimously concluded that "it has not been demonstrated that Mr Yasser Arafat was murdered by polonium-210 poisoning" and that the investigation should be dropped.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/english/adetails.php?fromval=1&cid=22&frid=22&eid=229052|agency=AFP|issue=02-09-2015}}</ref>
At the end of June 2016, a French Court of Appeal confirmed the previous conclusions.<ref>http://staging.hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_FRANCE_ARAFAT_DEATH?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2016-06-24-03-56-31{{full citation needed|date=February 2017}}</ref>
==Allegation of killing of Arafat by Israel== Israeli officials denied in 2012 any connection with the recent finds.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/world/2012-07/05/c_131697980.htm|title=Israeli officials deny Arafat poisoning rumors|date=5 July 2012}}</ref>
Israeli journalist [[Yossi Melman]], who specializes in espionage stories, reported that, based on his research with [[Dan Raviv]],<ref>released in their book ''Spies Against Armageddon: Inside Israel's Secret Wars'', {{ISBN|0985437812}}{{page needed|date=February 2017}}</ref> Israel did not kill Arafat. Melman stated that the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]] had wanted to take harsh action against Arafat, ranging from killing him to expelling him, but Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon|Sharon]] rejected these ideas, stating that the advantages wouldn't outweigh being accused of killing Arafat, and Arafat already seemed to be an irrelevant leader who wasn't trusted by the international community.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/07/10/israel-didn-t-kill-arafat.html|title=Israel Didn't Kill Arafat|work=The Daily Beast|date=10 July 2012|author=Yossi Melman}}</ref>
Journalist [[Danny Rubinstein]] states that Sharon's inner circle constantly discussed how to get rid of Arafat months and weeks before his death.<ref name=Guardian_polonium>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/nov/06/yasser-arafat-poisoned-polonium-tests-scientists'Yasser Arafat may have been poisoned with polonium, tests show,']. Angelique Chrisafis and Harriet Sherwood, ''The Guardian'', 6 November 2013</ref> Israeli peace activist and former [[Knesset]] member, [[Uri Avnery]], a personal friend of Arafat, blames Ariel Sharon for Arafat's death.<ref>[http://www.counterpunch.org/2013/11/15/the-assassination-of-arafat/ 'The Assassination of Arafat,'] at Counterpunch, 15–17, 2013.</ref> Palestinian official and nephew of Arafat [[Nasser al-Qudwa]] said that the report of the committee that investigated the death of late Palestinian President Yasser Arafat revealed that the leader was poisoned to death, and that Israel is directly responsible for his assassination. He said "Israel as a state, is a country that has access to Polonium, had the capability to assassinate the late leader, and expressed clear interest in getting rid of him".<ref>[http://www.imemc.org/article/66394 "Al-Qodwa: 'Arafat Died By Poison, Israel Responsible'"]. International Middle East Media Center (IMEMC), 12 November 2013</ref>
On 11 September 2003, the Israeli security Cabinet decided to "remove" Arafat. In a statement it said "Recent days' events have proven again that Yasser Arafat is a complete obstacle to any process of reconciliation... Israel will act to remove this obstacle in the manner, at the time, and in the ways that will be decided on separately..."<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/3102154.stm ''Excerpts: Israeli security cabinet statement'']. BBC, 11 September 2003</ref><ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/story/2003/09/12/israeli-cabinet-decides-in-principle-for-arafat-expulsion.html ''Israeli Cabinet Decides in Principle for Arafat Expulsion'']. FOX News, 12 September 2003</ref> Prime Minister Ariel Sharon refused to give a timetable for his removal, because "It depends on what happens on the ground,". Sharon said: "Arafat is responsible for the killing of hundreds, if not thousands, of Jews,...The sword is hanging over his head, and this is a good thing."<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/news/new-palestinian-cabinet-okd/ ''New Palestinian Cabinet OK'd'']. Ellen Crean, Associated Press, 29 September 2003</ref> Chief of Staff [[Moshe Ya'alon]] and other Israeli officials declared that the Palestinian leader should "either be killed or deported". Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said that Arafat impeded and undermined the peace process and urged states of the European Union to boycott Arafat.<ref name=alhram_647>[https://web.archive.org/web/20030811171247/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/2003/647/re2.htm Arafat vs Abbas]. ''Al-Ahram Weekly'', 17–23 July 2003, Issue No. 647</ref> Deputy Prime Minister Ehud Olmert told Israel Radio that killing Arafat "is definitely one of the options" under consideration by the government. A Security Council resolution demanding that Israel desist from deporting Arafat or threatening his safety was vetoed by the United States.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/24/opinion/24iht-edshlaim_ed3_.html ''Israel and Palestine : The real obstacle to peace is Sharon, not Arafat'']. Avi Shlaim, New York Times, 24 September 2003</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/whatkilledarafat/ ''Al Jazeera Investigates - What Killed Arafat?'']. Al Jazeera *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/4001697.stm ''International reactions to Arafat's death'']. BBC News. *[http://www.middleeasteye.net/essays/11-years-after-arafat-s-death-scientific-doubts-political-certainties-111041918 ''11 years after Arafat’s death: Scientific doubts, political certainties'']. Julien Salingue, MEE, 12 November 2015

'''Chore charts''' are also called reward charts, behavior charts, chore calendars, chore lists or task lists. A '''chore chart''' is a listing used to track and organize the [[house work]]. The [[chart]] can be physical or [[Virtuality|virtual]] and is often a means used by parents to post [[chores]] expected of their children.
Different homes have different ways of organizing and implementing a chore system, including simple paper charts tacked on the refrigerator. There has been a lot of research, experiential evidence and discussion of chore charts.<ref name="The Telegraph">[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=NTGB&p_theme=ntgb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=10B98D25041EDAF8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM The Telegraph]</ref><ref name="Denver Post">[http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=DP&p_theme=dp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAF44E58284CFC5&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM Denver Post]</ref>
== Age appropriate chores == Chore charts list household tasks, sometimes one chore chart per child and sometimes a combined list. Since children of different abilities and ages can handle various responsibilities, the chores featured on a chore chart can be divided by age.<ref name="Los Angeles Times">[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/58475642.html?dids=58475642:58475642&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jan+23%2C+1986&author=BONNIE+McCULLOUGH&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Getting+Kids+to+Help+With+the+Housework&pqatl=google Los Angeles Times]</ref> Younger [[children]] may not responsibly handle complex chores, but may still be able and want to help around the house.
== Reward for chores == While some parents do not give [[allowance (money)|allowance]] or [[Bounty (reward)|reward]] for household chores, there is evidence that allowance and reward helps to create financially sound adults and teach [[financial]] responsibility.<ref>http://www.investopedia.com/articles/pf/07/kids_allowance.asp?viewed=1</ref>
==See also== *[[Progress chart]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

A '''coroner''' in [[Washington state]] is a [[quasi-judicial]], public official principally charged with the certification of human death. It is completely identical in authority to the parallel office of '''medical examiner''', which also exists in the state. Washington uses a "mixed system" of death investigation with some counties employing coroners, and some employing medical examiners.
As of 2017, 24 of Washington's 39 counties have a coroner or a medical examiner. In 15 rural counties there are neither coroners nor medical examiners; duties normally performed by a coroner or medical examiner are instead discharged by the county's prosecuting attorney.
This article uses the term "coroner" to refer to coroners, medical examiners, and county attorneys discharging the duties of coroners.
==History==
===Background and early history=== The office of Coroner originated in England no later than 1194, though uncertain evidence indicates a possible older history.<ref name="psq">{{cite journal|last1=Gross|first1=Charles|title=The Early History and Influence of the Office of Coroner|journal=[[Political Science Quarterly]]|date=December 1892|volume=7|issue=4}}</ref> By the reign of [[Edward I]], there were four coroners in each county, elected to serve for life.<ref name="psq"/> Coroners were charged with recording and investigating deaths, of administering [[treasure trove]], and of substituting for the Sheriff when he was a party to a matter or incapacitated; the elected Coroner eventually evolved into a check on the power of the Crown-appointed Sheriff.<ref name="psq"/> The system of coronial death investigation was brought to North America by British colonists; one of the earliest coroners empowered in North America was appointed by [[William Penn]] in 1682 after a dead body was discovered on the banks of a river.<ref>{{cite web|title=Lycoming County Coroner|url=http://www.lyco.org/Elected-Officials/Coroner/History|website=lyco.org|publisher=[[Lycoming County]]|accessdate=September 3, 2017}}</ref> [[File:Caricature_drawing_of_D.C._Bates,_candidate_for_Thurston_County_(Washington)_Coroner,_c_1908.jpg|thumb|right|A caricature of D.C. Bates, candidate for Coroner of Thurston County in the 1908 election]] The [[Washington Territory]] was established in 1853 and, the following year, the Territorial Legislature passed "An Act Relative to Coroners" which required each of the territory's counties to organize an election for coroner and to hold a new election every two years thereafter.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Rochester|first1=Junius|title=Washington Territory and Washington State, Founding of|url=http://www.historylink.org/File/5661|website=HistoryLink|publisher=[[HistoryLink]]|accessdate=September 3, 2017}}</ref><ref name="wat">{{cite book|title=Journal of the Council of the Territory of Washington: Together with the Memorials and Joint Resolutions of the First Session of Legislative Assembly, Begun and Held at Olympia, February 27th, 1854|date=1855|publisher=Washington Territory|pages=105-106}}</ref> This act also authorized the Coroner to perform the duties of the Sheriff in certain matters:<ref name="wat"/>
{{cquote|The Coroner shall perform the duties of sheriff in all cases where the sheriff is interested, or otherwise incapacitated from serving; and when the coroner acts as the sheriff, he shall possess the powers and perform all duties of the sheriff ...}}
===Efforts at reform=== As early as 1907, legislative attempts were made to require elected coroners be licensed physicians.<ref>{{cite news|title=Walla Walla Undertakes Differ in Views on the Coroners' Bill|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/194795709/?terms=coroner|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=Evening Statesman|publisher=[[newspapers.com]]|date=February 1, 1907}}</ref> In 1913 the legislature abolished the office of coroner in all counties, except "counties of the first class" (the largest counties in the state), devolving the duties of coroner to the office of county attorney. However, A.R. Maulsby, the coroner of Snohomish County - an office which had been abolished by the statute - refused to stand-down, declaring the act of the legislature to be unconstitutional. The state's Supreme Court eventually sided with Maulsby, noting that the state constitution, as it then read, required a system of county government "uniform throughout the state". In 1948, the constitution was substantially amended to allow differential forms of county government in certain circumstances.<ref>{{cite web|title=County Forms of Government|url=http://mrsc.org/Home/Explore-Topics/Governance/Forms-of-Government-and-Organization/County-Forms-of-Government.aspx|website=mrsc.org|publisher=Municipal Research and Services Center|accessdate=September 3, 2017}}</ref>
In 1960 the Washington State Medical Association called for the complete abolition of the office of coroner, supporting its replacement with a system of state medial examiners and, in 1969, legislation was passed by the state's House of Representatives to do just that, however, the legislation failed in the state Senate.
===Contemporary status=== [[File:CoronersMEWA.png|thumb|Map showing Washington counties which have coroners (blue), medical examiners (red), or neither (grey)]] [[File:Coroner campaign sign.jpg|thumb|A campaign sign in the 2018 election for Coroner of Kitsap County, Washington]] [[File:Medical_Examiner_staff_member.jpg|thumb|A staff member of the King County Medical Examiner's office moves human remains in Seattle in 2016.]] The [[Revised Code of Washington]], as of 2017, provides for the creation of an office of coroner in each county with a population of 40,000 or more.<ref name="cdc">{{cite web|title=Washington|url=https://www.cdc.gov/phlp/publications/coroner/washington.html|website=Public Health Law Program|publisher=[[Centers for Disease Control]]|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref> In counties with a population less than 40,000, no independent office of coroner is authorized and the duties which normally fall to a corner are discharged by the county's attorney instead.<ref name="cdc"/> In addition, counties which have a population greater than 250,000 may choose to replace the office of corner with that of medical examiner.<ref name="cdc"/><ref name="WACME"/> Medical examiners are elected by the legislative authority of the county in which they hold office and are required to be certified as a forensic pathologist by the American Board of Pathology, while coroners are elected by the voters of the county in which they hold office and are required to have no qualifications other than the right to vote.<ref name="cdc"/><ref name="WACME"/><ref name="e">{{cite news|last1=Mattarresse|first1=Andy|title=Anybody can run for coroner, but does that mean they should?|url=http://www.dailyrecordnews.com/members/anybody-can-run-for-coroner-but-does-that-mean-they/article_f14e9ed4-e2e3-11e3-b6c3-0019bb2963f4.html|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=[[Ellensburg Daily Record]]|date=May 24, 2014}}</ref> <ref name="cdc"/><ref name="WACME">{{cite web|title=Coroner or Medical Examiner?|url=http://www.wacme.org/coronerormedicalexaminer.html|website=WACME|publisher=Washington Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref>
In 1968, prior to the enactment of the medical examiner statute, 17 counties had coroners while the remaining 22 counties had no coroners, the county prosecuting attorney discharging the duties of coroner, instead.<ref>{{cite news|title=Legislative Viewpoint|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/20137137/|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=Port Angeles Evening News|publisher=[[newspapers.com]]|date=April 19, 1968}}</ref> As of 2017 in Washington, 18 counties have coroners, six have medical examiners, and 15 have neither coroners nor medical examiners, the county attorney performs the functions otherwise discharged by a coroner or medical examiner.<ref>{{cite web|title=Death Investigation|url=https://www.islandcountywa.gov/Coroner/Pages/Investigations.aspx|website=Island County Coroner|publisher=[[Island County]]|accessdate=August 30, 2017}}</ref>
==Duties and authority== ===Acting Sheriff=== As of 2017, Washington law provides that a county coroner shall "perform the duties of the sheriff in all cases where the sheriff is interested or otherwise incapacitated from serving", wording unchanged from the original statute enacted by the Territorial Legislature in 1854. [[File:Thurston County Coroner.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the Thurston County Coroner's office in 2017]]
===Death investigations=== In general, deaths in Washington are either certified by physicians, or by licensed funeral directors using information obtained from a physician pertaining to a decedant's cause of death. Certification is made to one of a number of regional registries each administered by a designated "deputy registrar" who approves each addition to the death registry. However, state law provides that deaths arising from one of a list of prescribed mechanisms (including drowning, hanging, electrocution, radiation, sodomy, strangulation, etc.), or involving a healthy person who had not received medical attention in the 36 hours preceding his or her death, or in which the death occurred in a jail or prison, or in which the identity of the decedant is unknown, or in which the death occurred under suspicious circumstances, can only be certified by a county coroner. Physicians, deputy registrars, or any person discovering a body (such as a police officer) are legally obligated to refer these cases directly to coroners who are authorized to take possession of the body, to order a forensic autopsy on it, to pronounce the cause and mechanism of death, and to determine if the death was the result of unlawful homicide, which is necessary to bring criminal charges against a person.
In 2015, approximately 8.2 percent of all decedants in Washington were autopsied.
====Inquests==== The coroner is, additionally, empowered to convene an inquest to advise him on the cause of death prior to certifying the death. Inquests are conducted by a jury of at least four citizens convened by the coroner, hear evidence presented by him, and make an advisory verdict. The proceedings of an inquest are open to the public (investigations held outside an inquest are otherwise confidential and information produced by it - including autopsy reports - can only be released to certain individuals, such as law enforcement officers and next of kin).
The procedure is rarely used, but has been invoked on occasions where a death is controversial and the coroner feels public scrutiny would be warranted. In 2016, following the shooting death of an Hispanic man by police in [[Franklin County, Washington]], the coroner convened an inquest of six jurors - appointing three Hispanic persons to the jury - to ensure that "the public can’t say, ‘it’s the cops investigating the cops'".<ref name="nyt">{{cite news|last1=Oppel|first1=Richard|title=County Coroner in Washington Plans Inquest Amid Furor Over Police Killing|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/14/us/county-coroner-in-washington-plans-inquest-amid-furor-over-police-killing.html?mcubz=1|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=[[New York Times]]|date=February 13, 2015}}</ref> The inquest was only the third convened in Franklin County in the preceding twenty years and ultimately ruled the death was [[Justifiable_homicide#Examples_in_the_United_States|justifiable homicide]] by gunshot.<ref>{{cite news|title=Inquest Jury: Shooting Justified|url=http://kpq.com/inquest-jury-shooting-justified/|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=[[KPQ (AM)]]|date=December 15, 2016}}</ref><ref name="nyt"/>
Prior to 2016, coroners had the authority to issue arrest warrants should an inquest determine a cause of death as unlawful homicide.<ref name="herald"/> Since that time, a change in state law has required coroners to refer findings of homicide to a county prosecuting attorney for charging.<ref name="herald">{{cite news|last1=Cary|first1=Anette|title=Change in coroner inquest law affects Zambrano-Montes case|url=http://www.tri-cityherald.com/news/local/crime/pasco-police-shooting/article80217522.html|accessdate=August 26, 2017|work=[[Tri-City Herald]]|date=May 26, 2016}}</ref>
===Unclaimed remains=== Coroners are responsible for arranging for the disposal of human remains in cases in which "there is no other person willing to provide for the disposition of the body".
==Related agencies, organizations, and programs==
===Death Investigations Account=== The costs of retaining a forensic pathologist to conduct autopsies ordered by county coroners or medical examiners are reimbursed to counties by the state from the Death Investigations Account, which is held by the [[Washington State Treasurer]]. The account is funded from revenue generated by the state's Department of Health; eight dollars of the cost of every certified copy of a record produced by the department is deposited in the account.
===State Patrol Toxicology Laboratory=== The [[Washington State Patrol]] Toxicology Laboratory, located in [[Seattle]], performs testing on blood and tissue for the presence of drugs and alcohol at the request of coroners and medical examiners.<ref name="wsp">{{cite web|title=Toxicology Lab Division· Overview|url=http://www.wsp.wa.gov/forensics/toxicology.htm#contacts|website=WSP|publisher=[[Washington State Patrol]]|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref> As of the early 2000s, it conducted approximately 650 tests per year as part of coroner or medical examiner death investigations.<ref name="wsp"/> Established in 1963, the laboratory was accredited by the American Board of Forensic Toxicology in 2005.<ref name="wsp"/>
===Washington Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners=== The Washington Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners is a non-profit, non-governmental organization composed of the state's 39 coroners, medical examiners, and prosecuting attorneys who discharge coroner duties.<ref name="waco">{{cite web|title=Washington Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners|url=http://countyofficials.org/215/Coroners-and-Medical-Examiners|website=countyofficials.org|publisher=Washington Association of County Officials|accessdate=August 26, 2017}}</ref> It facilitates the exchange of information among officials and organizes [[continuing education]] courses on topics related to death investigation.<ref name="waco"/>
==Reserve assistant coroners== In 2001 [[Kitsap County]] created a program of "reserve investigative assistant coroners", what was at the time described as the first program of its kind in the state.<ref name="ksun">{{cite news|last1=McCormick|first1=Julie|title=Cororners-in-training|url=http://web.kitsapsun.com/archive/2001/04-26/0025_kitsap_county__cororners-in-train.html|accessdate=August 31, 2017|work=[[Kitsap Sun]]|date=April 26, 2001}}</ref> Under it, citizen volunteers who commit to 80 hours of classroom and field training can be appointed as part-time, unpaid assistant coroners in Kitsap County.<ref name="ksun"/> Reserve assistant coroners assist deputy coroners in transporting human remains, recovering bodies, and clerical duties.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kitsap County Coroner’s Office Rese rve I nvestigative Assistant Program Page 1 of 6 Kitsap County Coroner’s Office Reserve Investigative Assistant Program|url=http://www.kitsapgov.com/volunteer/pdf/Coroners%20Reserve%20Position%20Descrp%20Aug%202015.pdf|website=kitsapgov.com|publisher=Kitsap County Coroner|accessdate=September 25, 2017}}</ref> In 2002 the Kitsap County Coroner’s Office Reserve Deputy Coroner Program was disbanded. As of 2017, [[Lewis County, Washington|Lewis County]] had a similar program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Reserve Deputy Coroner/Internship Programs|url=http://lewiscountywa.gov/coroner/reserve-deputy-coronerinternship-programs|website=lewiscountywa.gov|publisher=Lewis County Coroner|accessdate=September 25, 2017}}</ref>
==Accreditation== As of 2017, the coroner offices in [[Cowlitz County, Washington|Cowlitz County]],[Lewis County, Washington|Lewis County]], [[Grant County, Washington|Grant County]], and [[Kitsap County, Washington|Kitsap County]] have been accredited by the [[International Association of Coroners and Medical Examiners]]. The medical examiner offices of [[King County, Washington|King County]], [[Pierce County, Washington|Pierce County]], [[Snohomish County]], [[Spokane County]], and [[Clark County, Washington]], have been accredited by the National Association of Medical Examiners (NAME).{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
The King County Medical Examiner’s Office first earned NAME accreditation in 1978; since then, the office has maintained accreditation, making it the longest running accredited Medical Examiner’s Office in the United States.{{citation needed|date=August 2018}}
