{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}}
<!--Please review the discussions at and preceding https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:No%C3%ABl_Coward/Archive_2#RfC:_Should_an_Infobox_be_added_to_the_page? before considering adding an infobox --> [[File:Noel Coward Allan warren edit 1.jpg|thumb|Coward in 1972]] '''Sir Noël Peirce<!--YES, it is spelled PEIRCE--> Coward''' (16 December 1899{{snd}}26 March 1973) was an English playwright, composer, director, actor and singer, known for his wit, flamboyance, and what ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine called "a sense of personal style, a combination of cheek and chic, pose and poise".<ref name=Time1969>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,941819-2,00.html "Noel Coward at 70",] ''Time'', 26 December 1969, accessed 2 May 2011</ref>
Coward attended a dance academy in London as a child, making his professional stage début at the age of eleven. As a teenager he was introduced into the high society in which most of his plays would be set. Coward achieved enduring success as a playwright, publishing more than 50 plays from his teens onwards. Many of his works, such as ''[[Hay Fever (play)|Hay Fever]]'', ''[[Private Lives]]'', ''[[Design for Living]]'', ''[[Present Laughter]]'' and ''[[Blithe Spirit (play)|Blithe Spirit]]'', have remained in the regular theatre repertoire. He composed hundreds of songs, in addition to well over a dozen musical theatre works (including the operetta ''[[Bitter Sweet]]'' and comic [[revue]]s), screenplays, poetry, several volumes of short stories, the novel ''Pomp and Circumstance'', and a three-volume autobiography. Coward's stage and film acting and directing career spanned six decades, during which he starred in many of his own works.
At the outbreak of the Second World War Coward volunteered for war work, running the British propaganda office in Paris. He also worked with the Secret Service, seeking to use his influence to persuade the American public and government to help Britain. Coward won an [[Academy Honorary Award]] in 1943 for his naval film drama, ''[[In Which We Serve]]'', and was knighted in 1969. In the 1950s he achieved fresh success as a cabaret performer, performing his own songs, such as "[[Mad Dogs and Englishmen (song)|Mad Dogs and Englishmen]]", "[[London Pride (song)|London Pride]]" and "[[I Went to a Marvellous Party]]".
Coward's plays and songs achieved new popularity in the 1960s and 1970s, and his work and style continue to influence popular culture. He did not publicly acknowledge his homosexuality, but it was discussed candidly after his death by biographers including [[Graham Payn]], his long-time partner, and in Coward's diaries and letters, published posthumously. The former Albery Theatre (originally the New Theatre) in London was renamed the [[Noël Coward Theatre]] in his honour in 2006.
== Biography ==
=== Early years === Coward was born in 1899 in [[Teddington]], [[Middlesex]], a south-western suburb of London. His parents were Arthur Sabin Coward (1856{{ndash}}1937), a piano salesman, and Violet Agnes Coward (1863{{ndash}}1954), daughter of [[s:A Naval Biographical Dictionary/Veitch, Henry Gordon|Henry Gordon Veitch]], a captain and surveyor in the [[Royal Navy]].<ref>Morley, p. 2</ref> Violet's cousin, Rachel Veitch, was mother of Field-Marshal [[Douglas Haig, 1st Earl Haig|Douglas Haig]].<ref>Hoare, p. 2</ref> Noël Coward was the second of their three sons, the eldest of whom had died in 1898 at the age of six.<ref>Morley, p. 3</ref> Coward's father lacked ambition and industry, and family finances were often poor.<ref>Morley, pp. 4, 8 and 67</ref> Coward was bitten by the performing bug early and appeared in amateur concerts by the age of seven. He attended the [[Chapel Royal]] Choir School as a young child. He had little formal schooling but was a voracious reader.<ref name=Kenrick1>[[John Kenrick (theatre writer)|Kenrick, John]]. [http://www.musicals101.com/noelbio.htm "Noel Coward – Biographical Sketch"], Coward 101 at ''Musicals 101: The Cyber Encyclopedia of Musical Theatre, TV and Film'', 2000, accessed 9 March 2009</ref>
Encouraged by his ambitious mother, who sent him to a dance academy in London,<ref>Hoare, p. 19</ref> Coward's first professional engagement was in January 1911 as Prince Mussel in the children's play ''The Goldfish''.<ref>"The Little Theatre", ''The Times'', 28 January 1911, p. 12</ref> In ''Present Indicative'', his first volume of memoirs, Coward wrote: {{quote|One day{{space}}... a little advertisement appeared in the ''[[Daily Mirror]]''.... It stated that a talented boy of attractive appearance was required by a Miss Lila Field to appear in her production of an all-children fairy play: ''The Goldfish.'' This seemed to dispose of all argument. I was a talented boy, God knows, and, when washed and smarmed down a bit, passably attractive. There appeared to be no earthly reason why Miss Lila Field shouldn't jump at me, and we both believed that she would be a fool indeed to miss such a magnificent opportunity.<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), pp. 21–22</ref>}}
[[File:coward Hawtrey 1911.jpg|left|thumb|Coward ''(left)'' with [[Lydia Bilbrook]] ''(centre)'' and [[Charles Hawtrey (actor born 1858)|Charles Hawtrey]], 1911]] The leading actor-manager [[Charles Hawtrey (actor born 1858)|Charles Hawtrey]], whom the young Coward idolised and from whom he learned a great deal about the theatre, cast him in the children's play ''[[Where the Rainbow Ends]]''. Coward played in the piece in 1911 and 1912 at the [[Garrick Theatre]] in London's [[West End theatre|West End]].<ref>Hoare, pp. 23–26</ref><ref name=times1912>"Garrick Theatre", ''The Times'', 12 December 1912, p. 8</ref> In 1912 Coward also appeared at the [[Savoy Theatre]] in ''An Autumn Idyll'' (as a dancer in the ballet) and at the [[London Coliseum]] in ''A Little Fowl Play'', by Harold Owen, in which Hawtrey starred.<ref>"The Savoy Theatre", ''The Times'', 26 June 1912, p. 10; "The Coliseum", 29 October 1912, p. 8; and "Varieties etc", 18 November 1912, p. 1</ref> [[Italia Conti Academy|Italia Conti]] engaged Coward to appear at the [[Liverpool Playhouse|Liverpool Repertory Theatre]] in 1913, and in the same year he was cast as the [[Lost Boys (Peter Pan)|Lost Boy]] Slightly in ''[[Peter and Wendy|Peter Pan]]''.<ref>"The Cult of Peter Pan", ''The Times'', 24 December 1913, p. 8</ref> He reappeared in ''Peter Pan'' the following year, and in 1915 he was again in ''Where the Rainbow Ends''.<ref>"Fairies at the Garrick", ''The Times'', 28 December 1915, p. 10</ref> He worked with other child actors in this period, including [[Hermione Gingold]] (whose mother threatened to turn "that naughty boy" out);<ref>Castle, p. 12</ref> [[Fabia Drake]]; [[Esmé Wynne-Tyson|Esmé Wynne]], with whom he collaborated on his earliest plays; Alfred Willmore, later known as [[Micheál Mac Liammóir]]; and [[Gertrude Lawrence]] who, Coward wrote in his memoirs, "gave me an orange and told me a few mildly dirty stories, and I loved her from then onwards."<ref name=times1912 /><ref>Hoare, pp. 27, 30 and 51</ref><ref name=times1916>"The Happy Family", ''The Times'', 19 December 1916, p. 11</ref>
[[File:Noel Coward in his teens.jpg|upright=.57|thumb|right|Coward in his early teens]] In 1914, when Coward was fourteen, he became the protégé and probably the lover of [[Philip Streatfeild]], a society painter.<ref>Hoare, pp. 33–34</ref> Streatfeild introduced him to Mrs Astley Cooper and her high society friends.{{#tag:ref|Evangeline Julia Marshall, an eccentric society hostess (1854–1944), married Clement Paston Astley Cooper, grandson of [[Astley Paston Cooper|Sir Astley Paston Cooper]], on 10 July 1877. She inherited Hambleton Hall from her brother Walter Marshall (d. 1899), and there she entertained rising talents in the artistic world, including Streatfeild, the conductor [[Malcolm Sargent]] and the writer [[C. K. Scott Moncrieff|Charles Scott Moncrieff]], as well as the young Coward.<ref>[[Simon Callow|Callow, Simon]]. [https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2006/apr/19/theatre "Englishman abroad",] ''The Guardian'', 19 April 2006, accessed 8 February 2009; [http://thepeerage.com/p25203.htm#i252021 "Evangeline Julia Marshall"], The Peerage, accessed 8 February 2009; and [http://www.hambletonhall.com/?about+us/Victorian-Hotel-History "History"], Hambleton Hall website, accessed 8 February 2009</ref>|group= n}} Streatfeild died from [[tuberculosis]] in 1915, but Mrs Astley Cooper continued to encourage her late friend's protégé, who remained a frequent guest at her estate, [[Hambleton Hall]].<ref>Hoare, pp. 39–43</ref>
Coward continued to perform during most of the First World War, appearing at the [[Scala Theatre|Prince of Wales's Theatre]] in 1916 in ''The Happy Family''<ref name=times1916 /> and on tour with [[Amy Brandon Thomas]]'s company in ''[[Charley's Aunt]]''. In 1917, he appeared in ''The Saving Grace'', a comedy produced by Hawtrey. Coward recalled in his memoirs, "My part was reasonably large and I was really quite good in it, owing to the kindness and care of Hawtrey's direction. He took endless trouble with me{{space}}... and taught me during those two short weeks many technical points of comedy acting which I use to this day."<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), p. 66</ref>
In 1918, Coward was conscripted into the [[Artists Rifles]] but was assessed as unfit for active service because of a tubercular tendency, and he was discharged on health grounds after nine months.<ref>Lesley, pp. 41–42</ref> That year he appeared in the [[D. W. Griffith|D W Griffith]] film ''[[Hearts of the World]]'' in an uncredited role. He sold short stories to several magazines to help his family financially.<ref name=Kenrick1 /> He also began writing plays, collaborating on the first two (''Ida Collaborates'' (1917) and ''Women and Whisky'' (1918)) with his friend Esmé Wynne.<ref>[http://www.noelcoward.net/html/plays.html "Plays and Musicals"], The Noel Coward Society, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> His first solo effort as a playwright was ''[[The Rat Trap]]'' (1918) which was eventually produced at the [[Everyman Cinema, Hampstead|Everyman Theatre]], [[Hampstead]], in October 1926.<ref>Thaxter, John. [http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/rattrap-rev.htm "The Rat Trap"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061215220640/http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/rattrap-rev.htm |date=15 December 2006 }}, British Theatre Guide, 2006, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> During these years, he met Lorn McNaughtan,{{#tag:ref|Later known by her married name, Lorn Loraine.<ref>Hoare, p. 79</ref>|group= n}} who became his private secretary and served in that capacity for more than forty years, until her death.<ref name=Kenrick1 />
=== Inter-war successes === In 1920, at the age of 20, Coward starred in his own play, the light comedy ''I'll Leave It to You''. After a tryout in [[Manchester]], it opened in London at the New Theatre (renamed the [[Noël Coward Theatre]] in 2006), his first full-length play in the West End.<ref name=Thaxter>Thaxter, John. [http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/illleave-rev.htm ''I'll Leave It To You''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110610013510/http://www.britishtheatreguide.info/reviews/illleave-rev.htm |date=10 June 2011 }}, British Theatre Guide, 2009</ref> [[Neville Cardus]]'s praise in ''[[The Guardian|The Manchester Guardian]]'' was grudging.<ref>Cardus, Neville. "Gaiety Theatre", ''[[The Manchester Guardian]]'', 4 May 1920, p. 13</ref> Notices for the London production were mixed, but encouraging.<ref name=Kenrick1 /> ''[[The Observer]]'' commented, "Mr Coward... has a sense of comedy, and if he can overcome a tendency to smartness, he will probably produce a good play one of these days."<ref>Ervine, St John. "At the Play", ''The Observer'', 25 July 1920, p. 9</ref> ''The Times'', on the other hand, was enthusiastic: "It is a remarkable piece of work from so young a head – spontaneous, light, and always 'brainy'."<ref>"I'll Leave It to You", ''The Times'', 22 July 1920, p. 10</ref>
[[File:Coward pestle.jpg|left|thumb|upright=.57|Coward in ''[[The Knight of the Burning Pestle]]'' in 1920]] The play ran for a month (and was Coward's first play seen in America),<ref name=Thaxter /> after which Coward returned to acting in works by other writers, starring as Ralph in ''[[The Knight of the Burning Pestle]]'' in [[Birmingham Repertory Theatre|Birmingham]] and then London.<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), pp. 104–05 and 112</ref> He did not enjoy the role, finding [[Francis Beaumont]] and his sometime collaborator [[John Fletcher (playwright)|John Fletcher]] "two of the dullest Elizabethan writers ever known ... I had a very, very long part, but I was very, very bad at it".<ref>Castle, p. 38</ref> Nevertheless, ''The Manchester Guardian'' thought that Coward got the best out of the role,<ref>"The Knight of the Burning Pestle", ''The Manchester Guardian'', 25 November 1920, p. 14</ref> and ''The Times'' called the play "the jolliest thing in London".<ref>"A Jacobean Romp", ''The Times'', 25 November 1920, p. 10</ref>
Coward completed a one-act satire, ''The Better Half'', about a man's relationship with two women. It had a short run at The Little Theatre, London, in 1922. The critic [[St. John Greer Ervine|St John Ervine]] wrote of the piece, "When Mr Coward has learned that tea-table chitter-chatter had better remain the prerogative of women he will write more interesting plays than he now seems likely to write."<ref>Ervine, St John. "New Grand Guignol Series", ''The Observer'', 4 June 1922, p. 9</ref> The play was thought to be lost until a typescript was found in 2007 in the archive of the [[Lord Chamberlain's Office]], the official censor of stage plays in the UK until 1968.<ref>Thorpe, Vanessa. [https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2007/sep/16/theatrenews.books "Coward's long-lost satire was almost too 'daring' about women",] ''The Observer'', 16 September 2007, accessed 22 September 2016</ref>
In 1921, Coward made his first trip to America, hoping to interest producers there in his plays. Although he had little luck, he found the Broadway theatre stimulating.<ref name=Kenrick1 /> He absorbed its smartness and pace into his own work, which brought him his first real success as a playwright with ''The Young Idea''. The play opened in London in 1923, after a provincial tour, with Coward in one of the leading roles.<ref>Hoare, pp. 89–91</ref> The reviews were good: "Mr Noël Coward calls his brilliant little farce a 'comedy of youth', and so it is. And youth pervaded the Savoy last night, applauding everything so boisterously that you felt, not without exhilaration, that you were in the midst of a 'rag'."<ref>"New Play at the Savoy", ''The Times'', 2 February 1923, p. 8</ref> One critic, who noted the influence of [[George Bernard Shaw|Bernard Shaw]] on Coward's writing, thought more highly of the play than of Coward's newly found fans: "I was unfortunately wedged in the centre of a group of his more exuberant friends who greeted each of his sallies with 'That's a Noëlism!'"<ref>"The Young Idea", ''The Observer'', 4 February 1923, p. 11</ref>{{#tag:ref|Coward himself acknowledged that Shaw's ''[[You Never Can Tell (play)|You Never Can Tell]]'' was the primary inspiration for ''The Young Idea''.<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), p. 114</ref>|group= n}} The play ran in London from 1 February to 24 March 1923, after which Coward turned to [[revue]], co-writing and performing in [[André Charlot]]'s ''[[London Calling!]]''<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), pp. 112 and 150</ref>
[[File:Lilian Braithwaite & Noël Coward.jpg|right|thumb|Coward with [[Lilian Braithwaite]], his co-star in ''[[The Vortex]]'' and the mother of his close friend [[Joyce Carey]]]] In 1924, Coward achieved his first great critical and financial success as a playwright with ''[[The Vortex]].'' The story is about a nymphomaniac socialite and her cocaine-addicted son (played by Coward). Some saw the drugs as a mask for homosexuality;<ref>Hoare, p. 129</ref> [[Kenneth Tynan]] later described it as "a [[jeremiad]] against narcotics with dialogue that sounds today not so much stilted as high-heeled".<ref name=tynan>Tynan, pp. 286–88</ref> ''The Vortex'' was considered shocking in its day for its depiction of sexual vanity and drug abuse among the upper classes. Its notoriety and fiery performances attracted large audiences, justifying a move from a small suburban theatre to a larger one in the West End.<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), pp. 182–85</ref> Coward, still having trouble finding producers, raised the money to produce the play himself. During the run of ''The Vortex'', Coward met [[John C. Wilson|Jack Wilson]], an American stockbroker (later a director and producer), who became his business manager and lover. Wilson used his position to steal from Coward, but the playwright was in love and accepted both the larceny and Wilson's heavy drinking.<ref name=Kenrick2>Kenrick, John. [http://www.musicals101.com/noelbio2.htm "Noel Coward – Biographical Sketch – Part II"], Coward 101 at ''Musicals 101: The Cyber Encyclopedia of Musical Theatre, TV and Film'', 2000, accessed 9 March 2009</ref>
The success of ''The Vortex'' in both London and America caused a great demand for new Coward plays. In 1925 he premiered ''[[Fallen Angels (play)|Fallen Angels]]'', a three-act comedy that amused and shocked audiences with the spectacle of two middle-aged women slowly getting drunk while awaiting the arrival of their mutual lover.<ref>"Fallen Angels", ''The Manchester Guardian'', 23 April 1925, p. 12</ref> ''[[Hay Fever (play)|Hay Fever]]'', the first of Coward's plays to gain an enduring place in the mainstream theatrical repertoire, also appeared in 1925. It is a comedy about four egocentric members of an artistic family who casually invite acquaintances to their country house for the weekend and bemuse and enrage each other's guests. Some writers have seen elements of Coward's old mentor, Mrs Astley Cooper, and her set in the characters of the family.<ref>Hoare, pp. 42–43</ref> By the 1970s the play was recognised as a classic, described in ''The Times'' as a "dazzling achievement; like ''[[The Importance of Being Earnest]]'', it is pure comedy with no mission but to delight, and it depends purely on the interplay of characters, not on elaborate comic machinery."<ref name=timesobit /> By June 1925 Coward had four shows running in the West End: ''The Vortex'', ''Fallen Angels'', ''Hay Fever'' and ''[[On with the Dance (musical)|On with the Dance]]''.<ref>Morley, p. 107</ref> Coward was turning out numerous plays and acting in his own works and others'. Soon, his frantic pace caught up with him, and he collapsed on stage in 1926 while starring in a stage adaptation of ''[[The Constant Nymph (novel)|The Constant Nymph]]'' and had to take an extended rest, recuperating in [[Hawaii]].<ref name=Kenrick2 />
Other Coward works produced in the mid-to-late 1920s included the plays ''[[Easy Virtue (play)|Easy Virtue]]'' (1926), a drama about a divorcée's clash with her snobbish in-laws; ''[[The Queen Was in the Parlour]]'', a [[Ruritanian romance]]; ''[[This Was a Man]]'' (1926), a comedy about adulterous aristocrats; ''The Marquise'' (1927), an eighteenth-century costume drama; ''Home Chat'' (1927), a comedy about a married woman's fidelity; and the revues ''On with the Dance'' (1925) and ''[[This Year of Grace]]'' (1928). None of these shows has entered the regular repertoire, but the last introduced one of Coward's best-known songs, "A Room with a View".<ref name=ncsongs>[http://www.noelcowardmusic.com/ncmi/appendices/appendix3.html "Appendix 3 (The Relative Popularity of Coward's Works)"], Noël Coward Music Index, accessed 29 November 2015</ref> His biggest failure in this period was the play ''[[Sirocco (play)|Sirocco]]'' (1927), which concerns free love among the wealthy. It starred [[Ivor Novello]], of whom Coward said, "the two most beautiful things in the world are Ivor's profile and my mind".<ref>Richards, p. 56</ref> Theatregoers hated the play, showing violent disapproval at the curtain calls and spitting at Coward as he left the theatre.<ref name=Kenrick2 /> Coward later said of this flop, "My first instinct was to leave England immediately, but this seemed too craven a move, and also too gratifying to my enemies, whose numbers had by then swollen in our minds to practically the entire population of the British Isles."<ref>Richards, p. 26</ref>
By 1929 Coward was one of the world's highest-earning writers, with an annual income of £50,000, more than £2,000,000 in terms of 2007 values.<ref>[http://www.measuringworth.com/ppoweruk/ "Purchasing Power of British Pounds from 1264 to 2007"], Measuring Worth website, accessed 10 March 2009</ref> Coward thrived during the [[Great Depression]], writing a succession of popular hits.<ref name=lahr93>Lahr, p. 93</ref> They ranged from large-scale spectaculars to intimate comedies. Examples of the former were the [[operetta]] ''[[Bitter Sweet]]'' (1929), about a woman who elopes with her music teacher,<ref name=C&N>Norton, Richard C. [http://operetta-research-center.org/coward-novello/ "Coward & Novello"], Operetta Research Center, 1 September 2007, accessed 29 November 2015</ref> and the historical extravaganza ''[[Cavalcade (play)|Cavalcade]]'' (1931) at [[Theatre Royal, Drury Lane|Drury Lane]], about thirty years in the lives of two families, which required a huge cast, gargantuan sets and a complex hydraulic stage. Its [[Cavalcade (1933 film)|1933 film adaptation]] won the [[Academy Award]] for best picture.<ref>[http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/DisplayMain.jsp?curTime=1386188010849 "Best Picture – 1932/33 (6th)"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221152803/http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/DisplayMain.jsp?curTime=1386188010849 |date=21 February 2014 }} Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, accessed 4 December 2013</ref> Coward's intimate-scale hits of the period included ''[[Private Lives]]'' (1930) and ''[[Design for Living]]'' (1932). In ''Private Lives'', Coward starred alongside his most famous stage partner, Gertrude Lawrence, together with the young [[Laurence Olivier]]. It was a highlight of both Coward's and Lawrence's career, selling out in both London and New York. Coward disliked long runs, and after this he made a rule of starring in a play for no more than three months at any venue.<ref name=Kenrick2 /> ''Design for Living'', written for [[Alfred Lunt]] and [[Lynn Fontanne]], was so risqué, with its theme of bisexuality and a ''ménage à trois'', that Coward premiered it in New York, knowing that it would not survive the censor in London.<ref>Hoare, p. 249</ref>
[[File:Novello-lunt-fontanne-campbell.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ivor Novello]], ''top l''., [[Alfred Lunt]], ''top r''., [[Lynn Fontanne]], ''lower l''. and [[Judy Campbell]]{{snd}}stars of Coward premières of the 1920s{{ndash}}1940s]] In 1933 Coward wrote, directed and co-starred with the French singer [[Yvonne Printemps]] in both London and New York productions of an operetta, ''[[Conversation Piece (musical)|Conversation Piece]]'' (1933).<ref name=Kenrick2 /> He next wrote, directed and co-starred with Lawrence in ''[[Tonight at 8:30]]'' (1936), a cycle of ten short plays, presented in various permutations across three evenings.{{#tag:ref|The cycle effectively comprised only nine plays: although Coward wrote ten works for the cycle, ''[[Star Chamber (play)|Star Chamber]]'' was dropped after a single performance.<ref>Hoare, pp. 268–70</ref>|group= n}} One of these plays, ''[[Still Life (play)|Still Life]]'', was expanded into the 1945 [[David Lean]] film ''[[Brief Encounter]]''.<ref>Morley, pp. 226–28 and 230</ref> ''Tonight at 8:30'' was followed by a musical, ''[[Operette (musical)|Operette]]'' (1938), from which the most famous number is "The Stately Homes of England", and a revue entitled ''[[Set to Music]]'' (1938, a [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] version of his 1932 London revue, ''Words and Music'').<ref>Morley, pp. 237 and 239</ref> Coward's last pre-war plays were ''[[This Happy Breed]]'', a drama about a working-class family, and ''[[Present Laughter]]'', a comic self-caricature with an egomaniac actor as the central character. These were first performed in 1942, although they were both written in 1939.<ref>Lahr, pp. 32 and 93</ref>
Between 1929 and 1936 Coward recorded many of his best-known songs for [[The Gramophone Company|His Master's Voice]] (HMV), now reissued on CD, including the romantic "[[I'll See You Again]]" from ''Bitter Sweet'', the comic "[[Mad Dogs and Englishmen (song)|Mad Dogs and Englishmen]]" from ''Words and Music'', and "Mrs Worthington".<ref>Naxos CDs 8.120559 and 8.120623</ref>
=== Second World War === With the outbreak of the Second World War Coward abandoned the theatre and sought official war work. After running the British propaganda office in Paris, where he concluded that "if the policy of His Majesty's Government is to bore the Germans to death I don't think we have time",<ref>Richards, p. 105</ref> he worked on behalf of British intelligence.<ref>Koch, Stephen. [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/13/books/review/Koch-t.html "The Playboy was a Spy"], ''The New York Times'', 13 April 2008, accessed 4 January 2009</ref> His task was to use his celebrity to influence American public and political opinion in favour of helping Britain.{{#tag:ref|[[Harold Nicolson]], speaking for the Ministry of Information, stated that Coward "possesses contacts with certain sections of opinion which are very difficult to reach through ordinary sources".<ref>Lesley, p. 215</ref>|group= n}} He was frustrated by British press criticism of his foreign travel while his countrymen suffered at home, but he was unable to reveal that he was acting on behalf of the Secret Service.<ref name=hastings>Hastings, Chris. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1568190/Winston-Churchill-vetoed-Coward-knighthood.html "Winston Churchill vetoed Coward knighthood"], Telegraph.co.uk, 3 November 2007, accessed 4 January 2009</ref> In 1942 [[George VI]] wished to award Coward a knighthood for his efforts, but was dissuaded by [[Winston Churchill]]. Mindful of the public view of Coward's flamboyant lifestyle, Churchill used, as his reason for withholding the honour, Coward's £200 fine for contravening currency regulations in 1941.<ref name=hastings />
Had the Germans invaded Britain, Coward was scheduled to be arrested and killed, as he was in [[The Black Book]] along with other figures such as [[Virginia Woolf]], [[Paul Robeson]], [[Bertrand Russell]], [[C. P. Snow]] and [[H. G. Wells]]. When this came to light after the war, Coward wrote: "If anyone had told me at that time I was high up on the [[Nazi]] blacklist, I should have laughed ... I remember [[Rebecca West]], who was one of the many who shared the honour with me, sent me a telegram which read: 'My dear – the people we should have been seen dead with'."<ref>Coward (''Future Indefinite''), p. 121</ref>
[[File:Noel Coward Entertains the Men of the Eastern Fleet, HMS Victorious, Trincomalee, Ceylon, 1 August 1944 A25390.jpg|thumb|left|Coward, with [[Norman Hackforth]] at the piano, performing for sailors aboard {{HMS|Victorious|R38|6}} in Ceylon, August 1944]] Churchill's view was that Coward would do more for the war effort by entertaining the troops and the home front than by intelligence work: "Go and sing to them when the guns are firing – that's your job!"<ref>Morley, p. 246</ref> Coward, though disappointed, followed this advice. He toured, acted and sang indefatigably in Europe, Africa, Asia and America.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,857528-1,00.html "Light Entertainment",] ''Time'', 19 July 1954, accessed 4 January 2009</ref> He wrote and recorded war-themed popular songs, including "[[London Pride (song)|London Pride]]" and "[[Don't Let's Be Beastly to the Germans]]". His London home was wrecked by German bombs in 1941, and he took up temporary residence at the [[Savoy Hotel]].<ref>Hoare, p. 317</ref> During one air raid on the area around the Savoy he joined [[Carroll Gibbons]] and [[Judy Campbell]] in impromptu cabaret to distract the captive guests from their fears.<ref>Hoare, p. 318</ref> Another of Coward's wartime projects, as writer, star, composer and co-director (alongside David Lean), was the naval film drama ''[[In Which We Serve]]''. The film was popular on both sides of the Atlantic, and he was awarded an [[Academy Honorary Award|honorary certificate of merit]] at the [[15th Academy Awards|1943 Academy Awards]] ceremony.<ref>[http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/DisplayMain.jsp?curTime=1386189663593 "In Which we Serve"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20131205161150/http://awardsdatabase.oscars.org/ampas_awards/DisplayMain.jsp?curTime=1386189663593 |date=5 December 2013 }}, Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, accessed 5 December 2013</ref> Coward played a naval captain, basing the character on his friend [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Louis Mountbatten]]. Lean went on to direct and adapt film versions of several Coward plays.<ref name=Kenrick2 />
Coward's most enduring work from the war years was the hugely successful black comedy ''[[Blithe Spirit (play)|Blithe Spirit]]'' (1941), about a novelist who researches the [[occult]] and hires a medium. A séance brings back the ghost of his first wife, causing havoc for the novelist and his second wife.<ref name=Kenrick2 /> With 1,997 consecutive performances, it broke box-office records for the run of a West End comedy, and was also produced on Broadway, where its original run was 650 performances.{{#tag:ref|The record (1,466 performances) had been held by ''[[Charley's Aunt]]'' since the 1890s.<ref>Gaye, p. 1525</ref> ''Blithe Spirit's'' West End record was overtaken by ''[[Boeing Boeing (play)|Boeing Boeing]]'' in the 1960s.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060321201520/http://www.globetheatrelive.com/20052006season/Blithe%20Spirit/Blithe%20Spirit%20Study%20Guide.pdf ''Blithe Spirit''], 2005/2006 Study Guide, Globe Theatre Guide, accessed 4 January 2009</ref>|group= n}} The play was adapted into a [[Blithe Spirit (film)|1945 film]], directed by Lean. Coward toured during 1942 in ''Blithe Spirit'', alternating the piece with his comedy ''Present Laughter'' and his working-class drama ''This Happy Breed''.<ref>Hoare, p. 331</ref>
In his ''Middle East Diary'' Coward made several statements that offended many Americans. In particular, he commented that he was "less impressed by some of the mournful little [[Brooklyn]] boys lying there in tears amid the alien corn with nothing worse than a bullet wound in the leg or a fractured arm".<ref>Calder, Robert. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HcpChZmn9s4C&pg=PA103&lpg=PA103#v=onepage&q&f=false ''Beware the British serpent''], p. 103</ref><ref>Hoare, p. 341</ref> After protests from both ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the Foreign Office urged Coward not to visit the United States in January 1945. He did not return to America again during the war. In the aftermath of the war, Coward wrote an [[alternate history|alternative reality]] play, ''[[Peace in Our Time (play)|Peace In Our Time]]'', depicting an England occupied by [[Nazi Germany]].<ref name=lahr93 />
=== Post-war career === Coward's new plays after the war were moderately successful but failed to match the popularity of his pre-war hits.<ref>Lahr, p. 136</ref> ''[[Relative Values (play)|Relative Values]]'' (1951) addresses the culture clash between an aristocratic English family and a Hollywood actress with matrimonial ambitions; ''[[South Sea Bubble (play)|South Sea Bubble]]'' (1951) is a political comedy set in a British colony; ''[[Quadrille (play)|Quadrille]]'' (1952) is a drama about Victorian love and elopement; and ''[[Nude with Violin]]'' (1956, starring [[John Gielgud]] in London and Coward in New York) is a satire on modern art and critical pretension.<ref>Lesley, pp. 314, 370 and 361</ref> A revue, ''[[Sigh No More (musical)|Sigh No More]]'' (1945), was a moderate success,<ref>Morley, p. 308</ref> but two musicals, ''[[Pacific 1860]]'' (1946), a lavish [[South Seas (genre)|South Seas]] romance, and ''[[Ace of Clubs (musical)|Ace of Clubs]]'' (1949), set in a night club, were financial failures.<ref>Lesley, pp. 248 and 289</ref> Further blows in this period were the deaths of Coward's friends Charles Cochran and Gertrude Lawrence, in 1951 and 1952 respectively. Despite his disappointments, Coward maintained a high public profile; his performance as King Magnus in Shaw's ''[[The Apple Cart]]'' for the Coronation season of 1953, co-starring [[Margaret Leighton]], received much coverage in the press,<ref>"Haymarket Theatre", ''The Times'', 8 May 1953, p. 12; and Brown, Ivor. "Royal and Ancient", ''The Manchester Guardian'', 8 May 1953, p. 5</ref> and his cabaret act, honed during his wartime tours entertaining the troops, was a supreme success, first in London at the [[Café de Paris (London)|Café de Paris]], and later in [[Las Vegas Strip|Las Vegas]].<ref>Morley, pp. 339–40</ref> The theatre critic Kenneth Tynan wrote: {{quote|To see him whole, public and private personalities conjoined, you must see him in cabaret ... he padded down the celebrated stairs{{space}}... halted before the microphone on black-suede-clad feet, and, upraising both hands in a gesture of benediction, set about demonstrating how these things should be done. Baring his teeth as if unveiling some grotesque monument, and cooing like a [[baritone]] dove, he gave us "I'll See You Again" and the other bat's-wing melodies of his youth. Nothing he does on these occasions sounds strained or arid; his tanned, leathery face is still an enthusiast's.... If it is possible to romp fastidiously, that is what Coward does. He owes little to earlier wits, such as [[Oscar Wilde|Wilde]] or [[Henry Labouchère|Labouchere]]. Their best things need to be delivered slowly, even lazily. Coward's emerge with the staccato, blind impulsiveness of a machine-gun.<ref name=tynan />}}
In 1955 Coward's cabaret act at Las Vegas, recorded live for the gramophone, and released as ''[[Noël Coward at Las Vegas]]''<ref>Reissued in 2003 on CD by CBS – DRG 19037</ref> was so successful that [[CBS]] engaged him to write and direct a series of three 90-minute television specials for the 1955–56 season. The first of these, ''Together With Music'', paired Coward with [[Mary Martin]], featuring him in many of the numbers from his Las Vegas act.<ref>Kenrick, John. [http://www.musicals101.com/noelbio3.htm "Noel Coward – Biography, Part III"], Coward 101 at ''Musicals 101: The Cyber Encyclopedia of Musical Theatre, TV and Film'', accessed 16 February 2009</ref> It was followed by productions of ''Blithe Spirit'' in which he starred with [[Claudette Colbert]], [[Lauren Bacall]] and [[Mildred Natwick]] and ''This Happy Breed'' with [[Edna Best]] and [[Roger Moore]]. Despite excellent reviews, the audience viewing figures were moderate.<ref>Payn and Morley, pp. 287–88, 304 and 314</ref>
[[File:Private Lives Theatre De Lys.jpg|left|thumb|"Dad's Renaissance": Coward's popularity surged in the 1960s; this poster features [[Al Hirschfeld|Al Hirschfeld's]] drawing of Coward rather than the stars of this 1968 revival.]] During the 1950s and 1960s Coward continued to write musicals and plays. ''[[After the Ball (musical)|After the Ball]]'', his 1953 adaptation of ''[[Lady Windermere's Fan]]'', was the last musical he premiered in the West End; his last two musicals were first produced on Broadway. ''[[Sail Away (musical)|Sail Away]]'' (1961), set on a luxury cruise liner, was Coward's most successful post-war musical, with productions in America, Britain and Australia.<ref>Lesley, pp. 410–14, and 428–29</ref> ''[[The Girl Who Came to Supper]]'', a musical adaptation of ''[[The Sleeping Prince (play)|The Sleeping Prince]]'' (1963), ran for only three months.<ref>Lesley, p. 430</ref> He directed the successful 1964 Broadway musical adaptation of ''Blithe Spirit'', called ''[[High Spirits (musical)|High Spirits]]''. Coward's late plays include a farce, ''[[Look After Lulu!]]'' (1959), and a tragi-comic study of old age, ''[[Waiting in the Wings (play)|Waiting in the Wings]]'' (1960), both of which were successful despite "critical disdain".<ref>[[John Simon (critic)|Simon, John]]. [http://nymag.com/nymetro/arts/theater/reviews/1773/ "Waiting in the Wings",] ''The NY Magazine'', 3 January 2000, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> Coward argued that the primary purpose of a play was to entertain, and he made no attempt at modernism, which he felt was boring to the audience although fascinating to the critics. His comic novel, ''Pomp and Circumstance'' (1960), about life in a tropical British colony, met with more critical success.<ref>Payn and Morley, pp. 451 and 453</ref>{{#tag:ref|Coward's fictional [[South Sea Islands]] colony, "Samolo", was loosely based on Jamaica, where he had a home; he used it as the setting not only for his novel, but for two plays (''Point Valaine'' and ''[[South Sea Bubble (play)|South Sea Bubble]]'') and a musical (''[[Pacific 1860]]'').<ref>Coward, ''Plays, Six'', p. xi</ref>|group= n}}
Coward's final stage success came with ''Suite in Three Keys'' (1966), a trilogy set in a hotel penthouse suite. He wrote it as his swan song as a stage actor: "I would like to act once more before I fold my bedraggled wings."<ref>Coward, ''Plays, Five'', introduction, unnumbered page</ref> The trilogy gained glowing reviews and did good box office business in the UK.<ref>Morley, p. 375</ref> In one of the three plays, ''[[A Song at Twilight]]'', Coward abandoned his customary reticence on the subject and played an explicitly homosexual character. The daring piece earned Coward new critical praise.<ref>"Noel Coward's Skeleton Feast", ''The Times'', 15 April 1966, p. 16</ref> He intended to star in the trilogy on Broadway but was too ill to travel. Only two of the ''Suite in Three Keys'' plays were performed in New York, with the title changed to ''Noël Coward in Two Keys'', starring [[Hume Cronyn]].<ref>Hoare, p. 502</ref>
Coward won new popularity in several notable films later in his career, such as ''[[Around the World in 80 Days (1956 film)|Around the World in 80 Days]]'' (1956), ''[[Our Man in Havana (film)|Our Man in Havana]]'' (1959), ''[[Bunny Lake Is Missing]]'' (1965), ''[[Boom! (film)|Boom!]]'' (1968) and ''[[The Italian Job]]'' (1969).<ref>Hoare, pp. 380, 414, 491, 507 and 508</ref> Stage and film opportunities he turned down in the 1950s included an invitation to compose a musical version of ''[[Pygmalion (play)|Pygmalion]]'' (two years before ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' was written), and offers of the roles of the king in the original stage production of ''[[The King and I]]'', and Colonel Nicholson in the film ''[[The Bridge on the River Kwai]]''.<ref>Hoare, pp. 387, 386, and 473</ref> Invited to play the title role in the 1962 film ''[[Dr. No (film)|Dr. No]]'', he replied, "No, no, no, a thousand times, no."<ref>Day, p. 310</ref> In the same year, he turned down the role of Humbert Humbert in ''[[Lolita (1962 film)|Lolita]]'', saying, "At my time of life the film story would be logical if the 12-year-old heroine was a sweet little old lady."<ref>Richards, p. 83</ref>
In the mid-1960s and early 1970s successful productions of his 1920s and 1930s plays, and new revues celebrating his music, including ''[[Oh, Coward!]]'' on Broadway and ''[[Cowardy Custard]]'' in London, revived Coward's popularity and critical reputation. He dubbed this comeback "Dad's Renaissance".<ref>Hoare p. 479 ''et seq.''</ref> It began with a hit 1963 revival of ''Private Lives'' in London and then New York.<ref>Morley, pp. 370–72</ref> Invited to direct ''Hay Fever'' with [[Edith Evans]] at the [[Royal National Theatre|National Theatre]], he wrote in 1964, "I am thrilled and flattered and frankly a little flabbergasted that the National Theatre should have had the curious perceptiveness to choose a very early play of mine and to give it a cast that could play the Albanian telephone directory."<ref>Morley, p. 369</ref>
Other examples of "Dad's Renaissance" included a 1968 [[Off-Broadway]] production of ''Private Lives'' at the [[Lucille Lortel Theatre|Theatre de Lys]] starring [[Elaine Stritch]], [[Lee Bowman]] and [[Betsy von Furstenberg]], and directed by [[Charles Nelson Reilly]]. Despite this impressive cast, Coward's popularity had risen so high that the theatre poster for the production used an [[Al Hirschfeld]] caricature of Coward (''pictured'') {{#tag:ref|The caricature was also used in connection with other Coward works, for example on his album of his ballet suite, "London Morning" (1959; reissued in 1978 on LP on DRG SL 5180 with the Hirschfeld drawing on the cover)|group= n}} instead of an image of the production or its stars. The illustration captures how Coward's image had changed by the 1960s: he was no longer seen as the smooth 1930s sophisticate, but as the doyen of the theatre. As ''[[New Statesman|The New Statesman]]'' wrote in 1964, "Who would have thought the landmarks of the Sixties would include the emergence of Noël Coward as the grand old man of British drama? There he was one morning, flipping verbal tiddlywinks with reporters about "Dad's Renaissance"; the next he was{{space}}... beside [[E. M. Forster|Forster]], [[T. S. Eliot]] and the [[Order of Merit|OMs]], demonstrably the greatest living English playwright."<ref>Ronald Bryden in ''The New Statesman'', August 1964, ''quoted'' in Hoare, p. 479</ref> ''Time'' wrote that "in the 60s... his best work, with its inspired inconsequentiality, seemed to exert not only a period charm but charm, period."<ref name=Time1969 />
=== Death and honours === [[File:Noël Coward Theatre 3.JPG|thumb|right|The [[Noël Coward Theatre]]]] By the end of the 1960s, Coward suffered from [[arteriosclerosis]] and, during the run of ''Suite in Three Keys'', he struggled with bouts of memory loss.<ref>Hoare, p. 501</ref> This also affected his work in ''The Italian Job'', and he retired from acting immediately afterwards.<ref>Lesley, p. 454</ref> Coward was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in 1969 and was elected a fellow of the [[Royal Society of Literature]].<ref>[http://www.ukwhoswho.com/view/article/oupww/whowaswho/U153506/COWARD_Sir_Noel?index=1&results=QuicksearchResults&query=0 "Coward, Sir Noël"], ''Who Was Who'', A & C Black, 1920–2008; online edition, Oxford University Press, December 2007, accessed 12 March 2009.</ref> He received a [[Tony Award]] for lifetime achievement.<ref>[http://www.noelcoward.net/html/chronology.html "Chronology"], The Noël Coward Society], May 2001, accessed 27 August 2008</ref> In 1972, he was awarded an honorary [[Doctor of Letters]] degree by the [[University of Sussex]].<ref>[https://www.sussex.ac.uk/webteam/gateway/file.php?name=list-of-honorary-graduates.pdf&site=76 "List of Honorary Graduates"], University of Sussex, accessed 17 December 2014</ref>
Coward died at his home, [[Firefly Estate]], in [[Jamaica]] on 26 March 1973 of heart failure<ref name=timesobit /> and was buried three days later on the brow of Firefly Hill, overlooking the north coast of the island.<ref>Wilson, Scott. ''Resting Places: The Burial Sites of More Than 14,000 Famous Persons'', 3d ed.: 2. McFarland & Company (2016) {{ISBN|0786479922}}</ref> A memorial service was held in [[St Martin-in-the-Fields]] in London on 29 May 1973, for which the [[Poet Laureate]], [[John Betjeman]], wrote and delivered a poem in Coward's honour, {{#tag:ref|"We are all here today to thank the Lord for the life of Noel Coward.<br />Noel with two dots over the 'e'<br />And the firm decided downward stroke of the 'l'.<br />We can all see him in our mind's eye<br />And in our mind's ear<br />We can hear the clipped decided voice".<ref>Lesley, p. 481</ref>|group= n}} John Gielgud and Laurence Olivier read verse and [[Yehudi Menuhin]] played [[Johann Sebastian Bach|Bach]]. On 28 March 1984 a memorial stone was unveiled by the [[Elizabeth Bowes-Lyon|Queen Mother]] in [[Poets' Corner]], [[Westminster Abbey]]. Thanked by Coward's partner, [[Graham Payn]], for attending, the Queen Mother replied, "I came because he was my friend."<ref>Day, p. 725</ref>
The [[Noël Coward Theatre]] in [[St Martin's Lane]], originally opened in 1903 as the New Theatre and later called the Albery, was renamed in his honour after extensive refurbishment, re-opening on 1 June 2006.<ref>Davies, Hugh. "Coward is the toast of theatreland again", ''The Daily Telegraph'', 1 July 2006, p. 14</ref> A statue of Coward by [[Angela Conner]] was unveiled by the Queen Mother in the foyer of the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane in 1998.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/230250.stm "Coward statue unveiled"], BBC news, 8 December 1998, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> There are also sculptures of Coward displayed in New York and Jamaica,<ref>[http://www.noelcoward.net/html/centenary.html "Centenary Year – 1999"], The Noël Coward Society, accessed 10 March 2009 and Koss, p. 163</ref> and a bust of him in the library in Teddington, near where he was born.<ref>{{NHLE|num=1396400 |desc=Teddington Library|accessdate=|ps=none}}, accessed 3 July 2014</ref> In 2008 an exhibition devoted to Coward was mounted at the National Theatre in London.<ref name=byrne>Byrne, Ciar. [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/theatre-dance/features/whats-inspiring-the-nol-coward-renaissance-771897.html "What's inspiring the Noël Coward renaissance?"] ''The Independent'', 21 January 2008, accessed on 17 March 2009</ref> The exhibition was later hosted by the [[Museum of Performance & Design]] in San Francisco and the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] in [[Beverly Hills]], California.<ref>[http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs078/1102539682978/archive/1102852501059.html "Coward on the Coast"], The Noël Coward Society, 27 November 2009</ref>
=== Personal life === [[File:Coward as Slightly.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Coward as [[Lost Boys (Peter Pan)|Slightly]] in ''[[Peter Pan]]'' in 1913]] Coward was homosexual but, following the convention of his times, this was never publicly mentioned.<ref name=C&N /> The critic Kenneth Tynan's description in 1953 was close to an acknowledgment of Coward's sexuality: "Forty years ago he was Slightly in ''Peter Pan'', and you might say that he has been wholly in ''Peter Pan'' ever since. No private considerations have been allowed to deflect the drive of his career; like Gielgud and [[Terence Rattigan|Rattigan]], like the late Ivor Novello, he is a congenital bachelor."<ref name=tynan /> Coward firmly believed his private business was not for public discussion, considering "''any'' sexual activities when over-advertised" to be tasteless.<ref>Payn, p. 248</ref> Even in the 1960s, Coward refused to acknowledge his sexual orientation publicly, wryly observing, "There are still a few old ladies in [[Worthing]] who don't know."<ref>Hoare, p. 509</ref> Despite this reticence, he encouraged his secretary Cole Lesley to write a frank biography once Coward was safely dead.<ref>Lesley, p. xvii</ref>
Coward's most important relationship, which began in the mid-1940s and lasted until his death, was with the South African stage and film actor Graham Payn.<ref>Payn, ''passim''</ref> Coward featured Payn in several of his London productions. Payn later co-edited with [[Sheridan Morley]] a collection of Coward's diaries, published in 1982. Coward's other relationships included the playwright Keith Winter, actors [[Louis Hayward]] and [[Alan Webb (actor)|Alan Webb]], his manager [[John C. Wilson|Jack Wilson]] and the composer [[Ned Rorem]], who published details of their relationship in his diaries.<ref>Hoare, pp. 162–63, 258, 261–62, 275, 273–74, and 469–70</ref> Coward had a 19-year friendship with [[Prince George, Duke of Kent]], but biographers differ on whether it was platonic.<ref>Hoare, p. 122</ref> Payn believed that it was, although Coward reportedly admitted to the historian Michael Thornton that there had been "a little dalliance".<ref>[http://www.express.co.uk/expressyourself/304572/Upstairs-life-of-a-royal-rogue "Upstairs life of a royal rogue"], ''[[The Daily Express]]'', 26 February 2012</ref> Coward said, on the duke's death, "I suddenly find that I loved him more than I knew."<ref>Lesley, p. 231</ref>
Coward maintained close friendships with many women, including the actress and author Esmé Wynne-Tyson, his first collaborator and constant correspondent; [[Gladys Calthrop]], who designed sets and costumes for many of his works; his secretary and close confidante Lorn Loraine; the actresses Gertrude Lawrence, [[Joyce Carey]] and Judy Campbell; and "his loyal and lifelong ''amitié amoureuse''", [[Marlene Dietrich]].<ref>Lesley, p. 176</ref>
In his profession, Coward was widely admired and loved for his generosity and kindness to those who fell on hard times. Stories are told of the unobtrusive way in which he relieved the needs or paid the debts of old theatrical acquaintances who had no claim on him.<ref name=timesobit /> From 1934 until 1956, Coward was the president of the [[Actors Orphanage]], which was supported by the theatrical industry. In that capacity, he befriended the young [[Peter Collinson (film director)|Peter Collinson]], who was in the care of the orphanage. He became Collinson's godfather and helped him to get started in show business. When Collinson was a successful director, he invited Coward to play a role in ''The Italian Job''. Graham Payn also played a small role in the film.<ref>Payn and Morley, p. 668</ref>
[[File:Sir Noel Coward Switzerland Allan Warren.jpg|thumb|upright|right|Coward in his home in Switzerland in 1972]] In 1926, Coward acquired [[Goldenhurst Farm]], in [[Aldington, Kent]], making it his home for most of the next thirty years, except when the military used it during the Second World War.<ref>Clark, Ross. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/property/3337128/Mad-about-the-house.html "Mad about the house"], ''The Telegraph'', 24 November 2004, accessed 27 August 2016</ref> It is a [[Grade II* listed buildings in Kent|Grade II listed building]].<ref>{{NHLE|num=1071221 |desc=Goldenhurst Manor|accessdate=|ps=none}}, accessed 24 August 2016</ref> In the 1950s, Coward left the UK for tax reasons, receiving harsh criticism in the press.<ref>Lesley, p. 355</ref> He first settled in [[Bermuda]] but later bought houses in Jamaica and Switzerland (in the village of [[Les Avants]], near [[Montreux]]), which remained his homes for the rest of his life.<ref>Lesley, p. 395</ref> His expatriate neighbours and friends included [[Joan Sutherland]], [[David Niven]], [[Richard Burton]] and [[Elizabeth Taylor]], and [[Julie Andrews]] and [[Blake Edwards]] in Switzerland<ref>Lesley, p. 437</ref> and [[Ian Fleming]] and his wife [[Ann Fleming|Ann]] in Jamaica. Coward was a witness at the Flemings' wedding, but his diaries record his exasperation with their constant bickering.<ref>Lesley, p. 310; and Payn and Morley, p. 463</ref>
Coward's political views were conservative, but not unswervingly so: he despised the government of [[Neville Chamberlain]] for its policy of [[appeasement|appeasing]] Nazi Germany, and he differed sharply with Winston Churchill over the [[Edward VIII abdication crisis|abdication crisis]] of 1936. Whereas Churchill supported [[Edward VIII]]'s wish to marry "his cutie", [[Wallis, Duchess of Windsor|Wallis Simpson]], Coward thought the king irresponsible, telling Churchill, "England doesn't wish for a Queen Cutie."<ref>Lesley, pp. 187 and 197</ref> Coward disliked propaganda in plays; "The theatre is a wonderful place, a house of strange enchantment, a temple of illusion. What it most emphatically is not and never will be is a scruffy, ill-lit, fumed-oak drill hall serving as a temporary soap box for political propaganda."<ref name=m101>Kenrick, John. [http://www.musicals101.com/noelquot.htm "Noel Coward 101: Cowardy Quotations"], Musicals101.com, The Cyber Encyclopedia of Musical Theatre, TV and Film, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> Nevertheless, his own views sometimes surfaced in his plays: both ''Cavalcade'' and ''This Happy Breed'' are, in the words of the playwright [[David Edgar (playwright)|David Edgar]], "overtly Conservative political plays written in the [[Bertolt Brecht|Brechtian]] epic manner."<ref>Kaplan, p. 4</ref> In religion, Coward was agnostic. He wrote of his views, "Do I believe in God? I can't say No and I can't say Yes, To me it's anybody's guess."<ref>Coward (''Not Yet the Dodo''), p. 54.</ref>{{#tag:ref|Coward also said, "I keep an open mind, but I will be somewhat surprised if St Peter taps me on the shoulder and says: 'This way, Noël Coward, come up and try your hand on the harp.' I am no harpist."<ref>Richards, pp. 64–65</ref>|group= n}}
Coward spelled his first name with the [[Diaeresis (diacritic)|diæresis]] ("''I'' didn't put the dots over the 'e' in Noël. The language did. Otherwise it's not Noël but Nool!").<ref>Richards, p. 58</ref> The press and many book publishers failed to follow suit, and his name was printed as 'Noel' in ''The Times'', ''The Observer'' and other contemporary newspapers and books.{{#tag:ref|Even Cole Lesley's 1976 biography refers to Coward as "Noel": "...I have also forgone the use of his beloved diaeresis over the 'e' in his name, having no wish to dizzy the eye of the reader."<ref name=lxx>Lesley, p. xx</ref>|group= n}} The papers of Noël Coward are held in the [[University of Birmingham]].{{#tag:ref|The papers were transferred from the flat of Mrs J. D. Hirst, Noël Coward's personal secretary, in January 2001.<ref>[http://calmview.bham.ac.uk/record.aspx?src=Catalog&id=XCOW "Noël Coward Collection"], [[University of Birmingham]], Cadbury Research Library, Special Collections, accessed 22 September 2016</ref>|group= n}}
== Public image == [[File:Coward with-cigarette-holder.jpg|thumb|right|The Coward image: with [[cigarette holder]] in 1930]] "Why", asked Coward, "am I always expected to wear a dressing-gown, smoke cigarettes in a [[Cigarette holder|long holder]] and say 'Darling, how wonderful'?"<ref>Richards, p. 59</ref> The answer lay in Coward's assiduous cultivation of a carefully crafted image. As a suburban boy who had been taken up by the upper classes he rapidly acquired the taste for high life: "I am determined to travel through life first class."<ref>Richards, p. 28</ref> He first wore a dressing gown onstage in ''The Vortex'' and used the fashion in several of his other famous plays, including ''Private Lives'' and ''Present Laughter''.<ref>Sacheli, Robert. [http://www.dandyism.net/?p=258#more-258 "Joyeux Noel"], Dandyism.net, 16 December 2006, accessed 17 March 2009</ref><ref>''Private Lives'', Act II, ''passim''</ref> [[George Walden]] identifies him as a modern [[dandy]].<ref>Barbey D'Aurevilly, p. 45</ref> In connection with the National Theatre's 2008 exhibition, ''[[The Independent]]'' commented, "His famous silk, polka-dot dressing gown and elegant cigarette holder both seem to belong to another era. But 2008 is proving to be the year that Britain falls in love with Noël Coward all over again."<ref name=byrne />
As soon as he achieved success he began polishing the Coward image: an early press photograph showed him sitting up in bed holding a cigarette holder: "I looked like an advanced Chinese decadent in the last phases of dope."<ref>Castle, p. 66</ref> Soon after that, Coward wrote, "I took to wearing coloured turtle-necked jerseys, actually more for comfort than for effect, and soon I was informed by my evening paper that I had started a fashion. I believe that to a certain extent this was true; at any rate, during the ensuing months I noticed more and more of our seedier West-End chorus boys parading about London in them."<ref>Coward (''Present Indicative''), p. 183</ref> He soon became more cautious about overdoing the flamboyance, advising [[Cecil Beaton]] to tone down his outfits: "It is important not to let the public have a loophole to lampoon you."<ref>Hoare, p. 201</ref> However, Coward was happy to generate publicity from his lifestyle.<ref name=Kenrick2 /> In 1969 he told ''Time'' magazine, "I acted up like crazy. I did everything that was expected of me. Part of the job." ''Time'' concluded, "Coward's greatest single gift has not been writing or composing, not acting or directing, but projecting a sense of personal style, a combination of cheek and chic, pose and poise."<ref name=Time1969 />
Coward's distinctive clipped diction arose from his childhood: his mother was deaf and Coward developed his staccato style of speaking to make it easier for her to hear what he was saying; it also helped him eradicate a slight lisp.<ref>Hoare, p. 16</ref> His nickname, "The Master", "started as a joke and became true", according to Coward. It was used of him from the 1920s onwards.<ref name=lxx /> Coward himself made light of it: when asked by a journalist why he was known as "The Master", he replied, "Oh, you know – Jack of all trades, master of none."<ref>Richards, p. 65</ref> He could, however, joke about his own immodesty: "My sense of my importance to the world is relatively small. On the other hand, my sense of my own importance to myself is tremendous."<ref>Richards, p. 67</ref> When a ''Time'' interviewer apologised, "I hope you haven't been bored having to go through all these interviews for your [70th] birthday, having to answer the same old questions about yourself", Coward rejoined, "Not at all. I'm fascinated by the subject."<ref name=Time1969 />
== Critical reputation and legacy == {{Main|Cultural impact of Noël Coward}}
The playwright [[John Osborne]] said, "Mr Coward is his own invention and contribution to this century. Anyone who cannot see that should keep well away from the theatre."<ref>[http://www.noelcoward.com/ "Noel Coward"], Introduction page to NoelCoward.com, accessed 8 February 2009</ref> Tynan wrote in 1964, "Even the youngest of us will know, in fifty years' time, exactly what we mean by 'a very Noel Coward sort of person'."<ref name=tynan /> In praise of Coward's versatility, [[Louis Mountbatten, 1st Earl Mountbatten of Burma|Lord Mountbatten]] said, in a tribute on Coward's seventieth birthday, "There are probably greater painters than Noël, greater novelists than Noël, greater librettists, greater composers of music, greater singers, greater dancers, greater comedians, greater tragedians, greater stage producers, greater film directors, greater cabaret artists, greater TV stars. If there are, they are fourteen different people. Only one man combined all fourteen different labels – The Master."<ref>Day, p. 3</ref>
[[File:Noel Coward (1963) by Erling Mandelmann - 2.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Coward in 1963]] Tynan's was the first generation of critics to realise that Coward's plays might enjoy more than ephemeral success. In the 1930s, [[Cyril Connolly]] wrote that they were "written in the most topical and perishable way imaginable, the cream in them turns sour overnight".<ref>Lahr, p. 2</ref> What seemed daring in the 1920s and 1930s came to seem old-fashioned in the 1950s, and Coward never repeated the success of his pre-war plays.<ref name=tynan /> By the 1960s, critics began to note that underneath the witty dialogue and the [[Art Deco]] glamour of the inter-war years, Coward's best plays also dealt with recognisable people and familiar relationships, with an emotional depth and pathos that had been often overlooked.<ref>Kaplan, pp. 7–13</ref> By the time of his death, ''The Times'' was writing of him, "None of the great figures of the English theatre has been more versatile than he", and the paper ranked his plays in "the classical tradition of [[William Congreve|Congreve]], [[Richard Sheridan|Sheridan]], Wilde and Shaw".<ref name=timesobit>"Obituary: Sir Noel Coward", ''The Times'', 27 March 1973, p. 18</ref>
A symposium published in 1999 to mark the centenary of Coward's birth listed some of his major productions scheduled for the year in Britain and North America, including ''Ace of Clubs, After the Ball, Blithe Spirit, Cavalcade, Easy Virtue, Hay Fever, Present Laughter, Private Lives, Sail Away, A Song at Twilight, The Young Idea'' and ''Waiting in the Wings'', with stars including Lauren Bacall, [[Rosemary Harris]], [[Ian McKellen]], [[Corin Redgrave]], [[Vanessa Redgrave]] and Elaine Stritch.<ref>Kaplan, pp. 217–21</ref> In another tribute, [[Tim Rice]] said of Coward's songs: "The wit and wisdom of Noël Coward's lyrics will be as lively and contemporary in 100 years' time as they are today",<ref name=m101 /> and many have been recorded by [[Damon Albarn]], [[Ian Bostridge]], [[The Divine Comedy (band)|The Divine Comedy]], [[Elton John]], [[Valerie Masterson]], [[Paul McCartney]], [[Michael Nyman]], [[Pet Shop Boys]], [[Vic Reeves]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]], Joan Sutherland, [[Robbie Williams]] and others.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/twentieth-century-blues-the-songs-of-noel-coward/oclc/44734242&referer=brief_results "Twentieth-century blues: the songs of Noel Coward"], [http://www.worldcat.org/title/ian-bostridge-noel-coward-songbook/oclc/815766527&referer=brief_results "Ian Bostridge: Noël Coward songbook"]; and [http://www.worldcat.org/title/sutherland-sings-noel-coward-songs-from-bitter-sweet-after-the-ball-and-more-featuring-noel-coward/oclc/51236890&referer=brief_results "Sutherland sings Noel Coward"], WorldCat, accessed 5 December 2013</ref>
Coward's music, writings, characteristic voice and style have been widely parodied and imitated, for instance in ''[[Monty Python]]'', ''[[Round the Horne]]'' and ''[[Privates on Parade]]''.<ref>"Sir Noel (Pierce) Coward", ''Cambridge Encyclopedia'', Vol. 69</ref><ref>Nichols, Peter: ''Privates on Parade'', Act 2, Scene 1 ("Noël, Noël")</ref> Coward has frequently been depicted as a character in plays,<ref>Hoare, Philip. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/3642513/Manuscripts-and-the-Master.html "Manuscripts and the Master"], ''The Daily Telegraph'', 22 May 2005</ref><ref>Martin, Dominic. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/4361/making-dickie-happy ''Making Dickie Happy''], TheStage.co.uk., 27 September 2004, accessed 4 January 2009</ref> films, television and radio shows, for example, in the 1968 Julie Andrews film ''[[Star! (film)|Star!]]'' (in which Coward was portrayed by his godson, [[Daniel Massey (actor)|Daniel Massey]]),<ref>[http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/75255/Star.html "Star! (1968)"] ''Time Out Film Guide'', accessed 16 February 2009</ref> the BBC [[sitcom]] ''[[Goodnight Sweetheart (TV series)|Goodnight Sweetheart]]''<ref>Grove, Valerie, "Carrying on Kenneth's pain", ''The Times'', 27 December 1997, p. 19 and "Book Now" ''[[The Independent]]'', 20 August 2008, p. 16</ref> and a BBC Radio 4 series written by [[Marcy Kahan]] in which Coward was dramatised as a detective in ''Design For Murder'' (2000), ''A Bullet at Balmain's'' (2003) and ''Death at the Desert Inn'' (2005), and as a spy in ''Blithe Spy'' (2002) and ''Our Man In Jamaica'' (2007), with [[Malcolm Sinclair (actor)|Malcolm Sinclair]] playing Coward in each.<ref>[http://www.noelcoward.net/html/audio.html "Audio and Broadcasts"], The Noël Coward Society, 2007, accessed 11 March 2009</ref> On stage, characters based on Coward have included Beverly Carlton in the 1939 Broadway play ''[[The Man Who Came to Dinner]]''.<ref>Isherwood, Charles. [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117787685.html "The Man Who Came to Dinner",] ''Variety'', 28 July 2000, accessed 16 February 2009</ref> A play about the friendship between Coward and Dietrich, called ''[[Lunch with Marlene]]'', by Chris Burgess, ran at the [[New End Theatre]] in 2008. The second act presents a musical revue, including Coward songs such as "Don't Let's Be Beastly to the Germans".<ref name=TheStage>Vale, Paul. [http://www.thestage.co.uk/reviews/review.php/20351/lunch-with-marlene "Lunch with Marlene"], ''The Stage'', 9 April 2008, accessed 29 March 2010</ref>
Coward was an early admirer of the plays of [[Harold Pinter]] and backed Pinter's film version of ''[[The Caretaker]]'' with a £1,000 investment.<ref name=hoare458>Hoare, p. 458</ref> Some critics have detected Coward's influence in Pinter's plays.<ref>Hoare, p. 269</ref> Tynan compared Pinter's "elliptical patter" to Coward's "stylised dialogue".<ref name=hoare458 /> Pinter returned the compliment by directing the National Theatre's revival of ''Blithe Spirit'' in 1976.<ref>[http://www.haroldpinter.org/directing/directing_spirit.shtml "Blithe Spirit by Noel Coward, The National Theatre, June 1976 (and tour)"] at haroldpinter.org, 2003, accessed 7 March 2009</ref>

In the society's second tier of favourites are: {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * "The Party's Over Now" (''Words and Music'') * "Dearest Love" (''Operette'') * "Dear Little Café" (''Bitter Sweet'') * "Parisian Pierrot" (''London Calling!'') * "Men About Town" (''Tonight at 8:30'') * "Twentieth Century Blues" (''Cavalcade'') * "Uncle Harry" (''Pacific 1860'') * "[[Don't Let's Be Beastly to the Germans]]" (1943) * "There Are Bad Times Just Around the Corner" (''Globe Review'') * "Dance, Little Lady" (''This Year of Grace'') * "Has Anybody Seen Our Ship?" (''Tonight at 8:30'') * "[[I Went to a Marvellous Party]]" (''Set to Music'') * "Nina" (''Sigh No More'') * "A Bar on the Piccola Marina" (1954) * "Why Must the Show Go On?" (''Together With Music'') * "Sail Away" (''Ace of Clubs'' and ''Sail Away'') * "Zigeuner" (''Bitter Sweet'')<ref name=ncsongs /> {{div col end}}
Coward was no fan of the works of [[Gilbert and Sullivan]],{{#tag:ref|"I went to ''[[Iolanthe]]''... beautifully done and the music lovely but dated. It's no use, I ''hate'' Gilbert and Sullivan".<ref>Day, p. 125</ref>|group= n}} but as a songwriter was nevertheless strongly influenced by them. He recalled: "I was born into a generation that still took light music seriously. The lyrics and melodies of Gilbert and Sullivan were hummed and strummed into my consciousness at an early age. My father sang them, my mother played them{{space}}... my aunts and uncles, who were legion, sang them singly and in unison at the slightest provocation."<ref>Programme note for ''[[Cowardy Custard]]'' (1972) quoting ''The Noël Coward Song Book''</ref> His colleague Terence Rattigan wrote that as a lyricist Coward was "the best of his kind since [[W. S. Gilbert]]."<ref>Day, p. 257</ref>

[[Image:KeepstoneFetchcropped.JPG|thumb|right|A [[Border Collie]] [[Sheepdog trial|herding]]. This behaviour is an example of modified prey drive.]] :''Eye-stalking, the tendency to watch potential prey, redirects here. For the study of eye movement, see [[eye tracking]]. For eyes on the ends of stalks, see [[eyestalk]]'' '''Prey drive''' is the [[instinct]]ive inclination of a [[carnivore]] to find, pursue and capture [[prey]]. The term is chiefly used to describe and analyse habits in [[dog training]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.darnfar.com/Dog%20Training/how_to_choose_the_right_breed.htm |title=How To Choose The Right Breed |publisher=Darnfar.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> ==Aspects== In all predators the prey drive follows an inevitable sequence: Search (orient, eye); Stalk; Chase; Bite (grab-bite, kill-bite); Dissect; Consume.<ref>{{cite book|last=Coppinger|first=Raymond|title=Dogs, A New Understanding of Canine Origin, Behavior, and Evolution|year=2001|publisher=University of Chicago Press|pages=116}}</ref><ref name=Lindley>[http://www.dogways.info/the-canine-prey-drive-instinct] article, "The Canine Prey Drive Instinct," Paul Lindley.</ref> In wolves, the prey drive is complete and balanced, as it utilises the whole range from search to kill, ending in the consumption of the prey.<ref name=Lindley/>
In different breeds of dog certain steps of these five have been amplified or reduced by human-controlled [[selective breeding]] for various purposes. The "search" aspect of the prey drive, for example, is most valuable in detection dogs such as [[bloodhound]]s and [[beagle]]s. The "eye-stalk" is a strong component of the behaviors used by [[herding dog]]s. The "chase" is seen most clearly in racing dogs such as [[Greyhounds]] and [[Lurcher]]s, while the "grab-bite" and "kill-bite" are valuable in the training of [[terrier]]s.
In many breeds of dog, prey drive is so strong that the chance to satisfy the drive is its own reward, and extrinsic reinforcers are not required to compel the dog to perform the behaviour.
==Benefits== In dog training, prey drive can be used as a performative advantage because dogs with strong prey drive are also willing to pursue moving objects such as toys, which can then be used to encourage certain kinds of behavior, such as that of [[greyhound racing]] or the speed required in [[dog agility]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thedogathlete.com/playing-with-prey-drive/ |title=Playing with Prey Drive: The Key to Attitude and Enthusiasm in Performance Dogs |publisher=The Dog Athlete |date= |accessdate=2011-12-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111127044930/http://www.thedogathlete.com/playing-with-prey-drive/ |archivedate=2011-11-27 |df= }}</ref> Prey drive can be an important component of pet [[dog training]], [[obedience training]] and [[schutzhund]] as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://flyballdogs.com/prey_drive.html |title=Understanding Prey Drive |publisher=Flyballdogs.com |date=1997-01-07 |accessdate=2011-12-06}}</ref> Games such as fetch and tug-of-war can be an effective motivator and reward for learning.
Certain aspects of the prey drive can be a disadvantage in some dogs. In [[retriever]]s, for example, the dog is expected to chase prey and bring it back to the human hunter, but not bite or damage it. Herding dogs must exhibit the stalking and chasing aspects of prey drive, but should have strongly inhibited grab bite and kill bite stages to prevent them wounding stock. [[Bull Terrier]]s such as the [[Staffordshire bull terrier]] have an amplified grab-bite as they were originally bred to [[bull-baiting|bait bulls]] (restrain bulls by hanging onto their noses), but never needed to find or stalk the prey.
==Degrees== Levels of prey drive often vary substantially in different dogs. Therefore, a dog with low drive does not make a successful detection or search dog, but a dog who is too high in prey drive may be unsuitable as a pet for a suburban home, as it may become bored and destructive when its high drive is not regularly satisfied.
==Balance== Dogs are happiest and most balanced in overall behavior when their prey drive is properly stimulated and satisfied through [[play (animal behavior)|play]]{{Citation needed|date=April 2017}}. Many professional dog trainers consider [[dog bite tug]] to be an effective training tool in prey drive and "retrieve" skills development.

Rev. '''Robert Eric Charles Browne''' (11 August 1906 – 1975)<ref name="death">''England & Wales, Civil Registration Death Index, 1916-2007''</ref> was a [[Church of England]] clergyman and religious writer.<ref name="crockford">''Crockford's Clerical Directory 1965-66'', Oxford University Press, 1967</ref>
==Career== Browne was born in [[Belfast]],<ref>''Ireland, Civil Registration Births Index, 1864-1958''</ref> the son of Canon John Edward Browne. He studied at [[Trinity College, Dublin]]. He obtained a B.A. degree from Trinity in 1928 and an M.A. in 1938. In 1929, he was ordained Deacon in the Church of Ireland by the [[Bishop of Down]], and he was ordained priest a year later.<ref name="crockford"/>
He served curacies in Belfast, initially at St Luke's and then at St Thomas. In 1942, he was appointed Chaplain of [[Saint Columba's College, Dublin]] (Rathfarnham) and in 1946 he moved to London to become the Secretary to the Theological Colloges department of the SCM (Student Christian Movement).<ref name="crockford"/>
Three years later he moved to Manchester and became Rector of All Saints, Gorton and in 1953 he became incumbent of the tractarian [[St Chrysostom's Church]] in [[Victoria Park, Manchester]], from which he retired, due to ill health in 1959. Browne was appointed an examining chaplain to the Bishop of Manchester in 1952 and a Canon of Manchester Cathedral from 1964.<ref name="crockford"/>
He died in Manchester in 1975.<ref name="death"/>
==Works== While Rector of [[St Chrysostom's Church]] Browne wrote two books, ''Meditations on the Temptations and Passion of our Lord'' (1955) and the influential{{citation needed|date=September 2010}} work ''The Ministry of the Word'' in 1958.
